dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rust-belt wakes. Iron bridges like spokes of a wheel. Wrecked fallow mills, reclaimed by nature. The massive br new grounded UFO that is Heinz Field, where the Steelers play. The converging three rivers aflame all the way to t picket fence of Allegheny Mountains beyond.

dialogues.speaker: MAN SINGING, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Ooh...and I like it/You send chills up my spine every time/I take a look at you/Ooh...and I like it-- (now we go into--) INT./EXT. BENNET’S CAR (MOVING) /PITTSBURGH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blue Mercedes E320 sedan and find BENNET OMALU, 35, shamelessly and sweetly singing.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I like the way you comb your hair/And I like those stylish clothes you wear/It's just the little things you do/That show how much you really care-- (singing his way through-) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  15 16 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 3. The Hill (ramshackle ghetto). Then Shadyside (leafy wealt Then the Strip (industrial hipsterville)-- BENNET (CONT’D) Like when I'm all alone with you You know exactly what to do-- Over a span of iron into a downtown of metal and glass--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ooh... and I like it/You send chills up my spine every time/I take a look at you/Ooh... and I like it/Ooh... and I like it-- (and--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet pulls up beside his car’s silver twin. Same make a model. In the shadow of a Victorian stone monolith chalke steel-mill soot. Itself in the shadow of a cloverleaf of humming freeway. And Bennet gets out. And we see-- He’s incongruously - exquisitely - dressed. Tailored suit Crisp shirt. Expensive tie (Presidential knot). Down a ra into a gaping basement, receding down a dark tunnel, we-- HEAR - IN PRE-LAP - PEOPLE SINGING (badly) “HAPPY BIRTHDA Happy birthday to you--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four TECHNICIANS celebrating a heavyset man's 50th. Cupca scrawled, “Happy Birthday Joe!" Balloon bouquet, a candle The break room. With a window letting out on the slabs. W a shitbox TV plays Wheel of Fortune. We’re in the POV of someone watching. The figure coming i focus in f.g., quarantined, isolated-- It’s Bennet. Standing - in scrubs now. Watching the other lips moving, laughing. Now grabbing portable CD player, a back to--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (pausing at the party) Gracie, may we begin, please? (and turns into--) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  17 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soaring tiled chapel-like chamber, floors sloped toward drains. Three steel slabs with fresh corpses in various states of disrepair, four more in bags against the walls. While in the b.g., DR. CYRIL WECHT, 60’s, in scrubs, step back from a slab to let a TECH finish up. Bennet and Wech meet in the middle of the room--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Good morning, Cyril-- As Wecht pats Bennet on the shoulder, moves to table to f out forms. Bennet checks the clipboard--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (checking the clipboard) Rachel Green first, please. GRACIE - early 20's, blue ribbon (matching her uniform) twisted through her hair - goes to what was a pretty WOMA like her, early 20’s. Still dressed for last night’s part

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: Full or partial, Dr. Omalu? Bennet reviewing the girl’s file. Police report. Holding her driver's license. Roots around in her purse. In b.g., prepping his own table, is DANIEL SULLIVAN, 50. Chief Pathology Supervisor. Bald, dark pouches under his eyes. Steelers stuff under lab gear. Countenance of an il humored butcher.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Open-shut O.D.-suicide. Full room today. We need to cycle them through. Bennet, moving slow, ignoring him, over the girl’s face, if listening.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I need your help, Rachel. We’re in this together. Tell me what happened to you. And a hand on the body’s forehead, another over the heart opens her eyes. Stares into them. Connection.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Oh here we go. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 4a.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Danny, c’mon. Let him do this thing. I hired him for a reason. (to Bennet) I need to talk to you. Come see me in my office when you’re done--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Full autopsy. We’ll need the tissue dissection station. Sullivan stops. Glares from his table. As a TRAINEE TECH, rolls a trolley over. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 5.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s not mine-- Gracie fetches a different trolley. Brand new knives stil plastic. Scalpels. The instruments longer, more delicate.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: (sidebars the trainee) Dr. Omalu uses different stuff. He makes less of a mess-- As Bennet sets the volume on his CD player--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Let’s undress her, please. And feels the fabric of her shirt. The quality. The patte

dialogues.speaker: TECH
dialogues.text: (measuring head to heel) Sixty-six-and-a-three-eighths.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Let’s please wash the body. And as the Trainee reaches for a Brillo pad, Gracie hands Bennet a sponge. And he starts carefully swabbing the bod himself. Pats it dry. Lovingly. As if dabbing a baby.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: (to the trainee) He likes to do it himself. (as--) Bennet puts on head phones. Through his ears, and ours, c the opening strains to Teddy Pendergrass’ “Love TKO”.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY PENDERGRASS, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Lookin' back over my years/I Bone saw, please-- guessed, I've shedded some tears/ Told myself time and time again/ This time I'm gonna win-- JUMP TO: Bennet hands Gracie an organ. We’re FRAMING high him, shoulders, elbows. We know but don’t need to see--

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY PENDERGRASS, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Think I'd better let it Liver nine-hundred fifty-two go/Looks like another love grams.

dialogues.speaker: T.K.0.--
dialogues.text: JUMP TO: he hands her another. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 6.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY PENDERGRASS, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Takin' the bumps and the Small tissue container. bruises/Of all the things of Freeze me a liver sample, a two-time loser-- please, Gracie. And lifts for the bone saw. JUMP TO: Bennet reaches toward the head. Cradles an orb o to Gracie as if a fresh loaf of bread.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Gracie takes dictation--) Possible causal relationship between early head trauma and self- medication leading to narcotics abuse and overdose--

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: (from across room) You're not her shrink, Bennet--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: If I know how she lived, I’11 know why she died. ANGLE on a window letting out on the chamber. Wecht stand there watching, shirt and tie, cinching the knot, turning the stairs, as--

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY PENDERGRASS, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Just tryin' to hold on, faith is gone/It's just another sad song-- JUMP TO: Gracie’s smock splashed with fluids and blood. ( is everyone else’s). Bennet’s pristine. Until some small fleck spray lands, and-- He immediately slips off his plastic smock. Gracie - know him - slips a fresh one on.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY PENDERGRASS, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Takin' the bumps and the bruises/Of all the things of a two-time loser/See I try to hold on, my faith-- Now silence. Body reassembled. Bennet’s fingers resting o the girl’s hand. Feeling for spiritual pulse. On Bennet’s face, peace. As Gracie zips up the body bag. And Sullivan glares--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Careful, Daniel. One day I might be rushing through your autopsy. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  18 19 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 7.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (and throwing the used knife into ‘hazardous waste’--)

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: INT. WECHT’S OFFICE - ALLEGHENY COUNTY CORONER - DAY Sits across from CYRIL WECHT, Chief Medical Examiner. 60' celebrity pathologist: array of pictures with Elvis’ body JonBenet Ramsey's files; at the JFK assassination hearing Both in suit and tie. Wecht’s eating a bagel. Pulls a bot of Johnny Walker from his drawer and pours a couple.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: You know the reason you’re not back in Nigeria?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET WECHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I remind you of you. Only less handsome. Wecht motions to Bennet’s collar. Something there. Bennet brushes it off. And we realize: they are in identical sui Except - Wecht points - to Bennet’s chest pocket-- WECHT (CONT’D) I don’t have any. What the hell are they for, anyway? Just fill up with schmutz-— (nods at autopsy chamber) What the hell’s going on in there?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I’m doing my work. I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: You're not fine. Danny hates your guts. I’ve never seen anything like it. (pause) You take too much time, Bennet.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: The dead are my patients. I treat them with respect.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Treat them however you want, but do you have to talk to them? Maybe just talk to them in your head while you’re - you know - working-- (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 8.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Bennet’s giving nothing) And we talked about the knives. You're still throwing them away. They're expensive. This is Pittsburgh. We’re a public agency.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Would you want me to cut open your mother with the knife I used on a serial killer?

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Don’t tempt me. I’d probably request it. Wecht sighs. Bennet’s not wrong. But still-- WECHT (CONT’D) Danny may look like a butcher, smokes three packs a day, but he’s one of life’s unpleasant necessities. You’ll probably do his goddamn autopsy soon--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: That’s what I told him.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: I know you did. He told me. Why are you antagonizing him? (and looks at him) You need a girlfriend. You have to touch someone alive once in a while. Living women are a pain in the ass. But occasionally they’re amazing. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So maybe just a little less of an artist? Be yourself, just play the game a little, okay? (as he slides across a thick file--)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (can’t do it--) I have exams next week.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Death row case. The guy’s being railroaded. A thousand dollars for you. Bennet looks at him. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  20 21 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 9.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: How do you become a professional expert witness?

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: It’s not a profession, it’s a hobby. You and I have jobs, right? So instead of watching baseball - or playing bridge with my wife - I do this. Besides, by the time your balls are hanging as low as mine, you better be expert in something.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: You're the best, Cyril.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Well, if you don’t piss everyone off, you’re going to be better. And Bennet leans into crime scene photos, police and forensics reports. Young woman ripped and bloodied. INT. BENNET’S OFFICE - COUNTY CORONER - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet in his shitbox storage closet re-fitted as an offi (We clock the high-school quality microscope he’s been gi The crappy ancient computer. All his framed degrees stack on the floor; no room to hang even one) He roots in his pocket for a small rusty crucifix, sets i his desk, and settles in amidst boxes of files. Crime sce photos. Bearing down into the paper with his machine-like focus. Then stops. Closes the file. Gets up, reaching for his co Now, OVER this, in PRE-LAP, we start to HEAR the infinity thud of contempo-dance, and we cut to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8,000 sq. ft. of throbbing university jocks, yuppies, mod wannabes. Celo lights strobing to Kylie Minogue. CAMERA FINDS BENNET flush to a speaker, gripping a Heinek Fastidiously dressed even here, pressed jeans, buttoned p Good with rhythm, willing the bass and music to wash thro © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  22 23 24 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 10. But a man apart in every way: he’s black, but no one else here is. Doesn’t notice, doesn’t care. Just grooves solo the mathematics of the music. His eyes close, and-- We MUTE and go in there. His head. Where there’s nothing limbic throb. And disconnect. And so peace. His face plac Happy. HOLD a long beat, then-- IT’S 3AM And we've gone ravey electronica. Bennet’s moves liquid. of that peace. HOLD on him in his solo bliss, then cut to INT. BENNET’S CONDO - NIGHT/PRE-DAWN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EYES FOCUSED like cameras on the crime scene photos from death row case. Spread across a kitchen table. BACK TO REVEAL Bennet, there, still in club clothes. The notes he takes calligraphy-neat. Bachelor pad sparse. Microscope on the table. Forest of t books. Squared and aligned, like his-- Closet. Shirts and suits precision-hangered by color. A r of ties pre-knotted. Shoes lined up like soldiers. Now-- Back to Bennet. At his computer. Which we see has a Pope Paul II screen-saver. Pope’s watching him. Watching over- Bennet’s searing focus. And then-- And Bennet is finally asleep atop his bed. Then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pale marble. White leather appointments. A sprawling view Pittsburgh. The antisepsis of influence and success. WE FIND BENNET alone amidst the furniture. Briefcase on h lap. JUMP TO SAME AN HOUR LATER. Bennet hasn’t moved. One of t PARTNERS - MR. CROCKETT - sticks his head in. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 11.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: (ignores Bennet) You sure Dr. Bennet hasn’t come through? He was supposed to be here an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I am Dr. Bennet Omalu.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: Doctor Bennet? Omalu? (Bennet stands, and--)

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, Mr. Crockett. I thought he was here for the clerk job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Partner leads Bennet to a conference room. Huge table cov in files and laptops. A half-dozen ATTORNEYS huddle waiti

dialogues.speaker: SCARBOROUGH
dialogues.text: (looking up, confused) Where’s Cyril?

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Bennet Omalu.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I work for Dr. Wecht. (after a pause, you gotta be kidding me--)

dialogues.speaker: SCARBOROUGH
dialogues.text: Our guy’s gonna be put to death in thirty days, and we were supposed to get the Hail Mary expert witness, and Cyril sends us this? No offense.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (a smile, none taken) Your client didn’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: SCARBOROUGH
dialogues.text: We know that.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: You may know. But I can prove it. (and we cut, and--) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  26 27 28 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE of a weed-strewn empty lot. A king-cab Chevy pick-up the lee of abandoned construction. Side windows blown, replaced with garbage bags. As a Harley bike ENTERS FRAME crossing to the pick-up, cu A_REAR-VIEW MIRROR. In them, eyes, slightly mad, trying to recognize their ow reflection. They fill the screen, then we WIDEN TO--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIKE WEBSTER, 50 but looks 70. Unwashed. Hair stringy. Granular thickness everywhere, forehead barnacled with sc Fingers mangled in a permanent curl, as if gripping a bal Surrounded by soiled clothes and Ding-Dong wrappers. Cruc dangles from the mirror. Piles of lined yellow paper. Covered edge to edge in scra An equally massive MAN dismounts the bike: 6'8”, 320 lbs: JUSTIN STRZELCZYK (Strel-zik), 36. Heavy-bearded, plaid shirt, overalls. A giant hippie.

dialogues.speaker: STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: Webby, hey man, love your digs! (no response) Webby, it’s Jugger! (then) Mike. It’s Justin. (Webster turning his big head, no recognition) I'll just sit with you a minute? And slips behind the wheel. Smells like ass. On the passe seat: container of ammonia; super-glue.

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: (awakening to where he is) Where is this?

dialogues.speaker: STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: This is Ohio. Off some freeway.

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: Ohio’s got the best truck stops. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 13.

dialogues.speaker: STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: But this ain’t even that. This is -- I don’t know what this is. Strzelczyk picks at the yellow paper. Starts to read. The Reaches for Webster’s knee. STRZELCZYK (CONT’D) My brother. Been looking for you. Pam said I might find you here. (which taps Webster into momentary focus)

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: Juggers.

dialogues.speaker: STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: We’re all worried about you. And takes a wad of toilet tissue dipped in ammonia, puts to his face. Eyes flare -- “Don’t do that” -- “Keeps me awake! Don’t want to fall asleep!” -- Strzelczyk grabs fo the wad -- “What the -- Mike!” -- two tree-trunk arms sho hands slap at it--

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: Don’t wanna fall asleep don’t wanna fall asleep can’t fall asleep-- A glimpse of the mess of Webster’s mouth: teeth glued bac in, gums bloody.

dialogues.speaker: STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: You gotta let me take you back. (Webster can’t remember) You called an audible, Mike. You took off. (pause; then) I heard you sold your Super Bowl rings. Your rings, man. Webster non-responsive. Then gets out of the truck. Agita Can’t get the words out. Strzelczyk gets out his side, co around. Right up into Webster-- STRZELCZYK (CONT’D) Pam is your wife. Garrett, your boy-

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: (announcer voice) --was so ugly when he was born his momma carried him around upside down for a week, thought he only had one eye! © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 14. Laugh line. But no one laughs.

dialogues.speaker: STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: (squeezes Webster’s hands) Mike. My knees are shot. I retired. I’m done. I just wanted you to know. (then; afraid) What happens when Mike Webster falls asleep?

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: He remembers.

dialogues.speaker: STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: I’m starting to forget things, Webby. I’m hearing myself say this stupid crap to my kids. I almost pushed Keana into a wall, man. I never touched a girl like that. Webster looks at him. Then getting back into the truck--

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: Don’t give up, son! (Strzelczyk leaves a roll of hundreds, walks) Finish the game and we'll all be winners! (Strzelczyk gets on his bike and--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big rangy house of a pro athlete. Strzelczyk playing guit on his porch, some mournful melody. Soft voice incongruou with his giantness. Flanked by his SON, 9, DAUGHTER, 6. Car pulls up. Wife, KEANA -- 30, thin, angular face, the opposite of Strzelczyk -- crosses to him with groceries.

dialogues.speaker: KEANA STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: He really sell his rings? (he stops playing--)

dialogues.speaker: STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: That wasn’t Webby. Webby’s gone. I don’t know who that was. (and back to--) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  29 30 31 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plastic bags taped to the windows breathing in and ou like a bellows. Webster failing at sleep. Stretches across the trash. The fetal. Now sits up. Everything hurts. The mosquitoes rage Can't find stillness. He grips his head. Searing hot pain He reaches for a Taser. Charges it. The prongs jack up. A loud crack, like a gunshot. Primed and ready. He’s sweaty. Desperate for sleep now. Pushes down his pan Thigh flesh already burnt. Charred in places. Brings the Taser to his own meat -- doesn’t even flinch - triggers -- CRACK! -- blue flash. And Webster's bulk is r dolled onto the floor of the truck, and we cut to black-- OVER BLACK, in PRE-LAP -- RAP RAP RAP -- the crack of met on window glass, then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Webster - hideously unclean, mouth a cesspool - wakes in entirely different location. Forehead-down into the steer wheel. Security Guard, 60, knocking at his window. He ope

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Mike Webster, right? Iron Mike? Webster isn’t entirely sure. Of that, or how he got here. Looks up to see he’s parked in front of medical offices. The guard thrusts his electric bill at him. SECURITY GUARD (CONT’D) Can you sign this? My wife’s gonna. Freak. Out. Some part of Webster remembers what to do. He scribbles something. Then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON A SURGEON peering through magnifiers into the sheeted window into an open skull. Fingers probe, snip, suture with the precision of a watch repair. The brain a living breathing seeping organism. Now surgeon’s done. An slips down his mask, and we've met DR. JULIAN BAILES, 46. A NURSE - “Dr. Bailes” - whispers in his ear, and-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  32 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bailes - still in scrubs - following his ASSISTANT to his door. Louisiana Methodist. Wrapped tight. Big gold watch. Steelers Superbowl ring on his hand. Office draped in family, God and football: bible; framed photos of southern-belle WIFE, five KIDS; Bailes as colle linebacker; shelf full of helmets: Steelers, Cardinals. Everything else is Steelers: framed photo of LYNN SWANN m air. Others of Bailes on game-time sidelines. With the Lombardi Trophy. Under the same post-game confetti as Webster. To find Webster pacing in his manic shambles--

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: What do I do I am freakin overwhelmed--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES WEBSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're going to get you some Ritalin. help. What are you taking?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES WEBSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What about Dexedrine? The Superglue. Prozac? Klonopin? Still taking all that?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Call Pam. Tell her we found him. Tell her he’s worse.

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER BAILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You -- you were my doctor-- Team doctor, Mike. I was everybody’s doctor. Webster punching the side of his head. Bangs his fists against his prodigious chest.

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: Fix it! In here! In here! I’m dying in here! Bailes’ Assistant is in with a loaded syringe -- “Haldol cc’s” -- Webster sweaty -- waving his arms. Bailes inject As the giant body pours into a chair--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: What am I missing? Tumor? © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  33

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: His scans are normal-- (and as he stares at Webster, stumped--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gallery standing room only. The accused, THOMAS KIMBLE 40, hulkish in his orange jumpsuit.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: (to the court) The state has asked, after a lengthy trial, a death sentence, and two appeals, why would we learn something new about this case from you? (then) Dr. Omalu. Do you have a medical degree?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Yes. From the University of Nigeria, in Enugu, Nigeria. (and then) I did my residency at the Columbia University Medical School in New York. I have masters degrees in Public Health and Epidemiology. In addition, I am a certified physician executive, and a specialist in Emergency medicine. And I am of course board certified in Forensic Pathology, Clinical Pathology and Anatomic Pathology. My specialty is Neuro-pathology, the examination of the brain-- Crockett about to move in-- BENNET (CONT’D) So sorry-- (not done) And I am completing my MBA at Carnegie Mellon University.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: While working as a Medical Examiner at the Allegheny County Coroner?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Yes. (and) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 18.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And, oh yes, before I arrived in America, a masters in Theory of Music from the Royal School of Music in London. (big easy smile incongruous to where he sits, then) To answer your question, my specialty is the science of death. I think more about why people die than I do about the way people live. (room quiet, awestruck) I very carefully re-studied the interviews with the defendant, Mr. Kimble. And of course the autopsy reports on the victim, who was killed quite brutally with bare hands. Reaches for a stack of blown-up photos. Top photo: hands shredded, bone-crushed. Grey with death. BENNET (CONT’D) Hands of the deceased. Broken nails. Blood under the nails. Bite marks. Contusions. The hands of a woman who fought wildly for her life - and lost. Now a set of male hands. Splashed in blood.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: Are these hands not Mr. Kimble’s?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: They are indeed Mr. Kimble’s.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: Doesn't that suggest that the state has the right man?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I thought so. Until I heard hour two-hundred seventeen of Mr. Kimble’s police interview. He was speaking quietly, and off-mic, but I clearly heard him say- (reads from notes) “I don’t like blood. When I was a kid I had a tooth pulled and I wouldn't stop bleeding. My parents wouldn’t let me play outside somtimes--" © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 19. And we REVERSE on the Prosecutor. On the cusp of realizat

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I saw no reference to this in any trial transcript. I got curious.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Hands. Bennet holds up the victim’s hands alongside Kimble’s han BENNET (CONT’D) Mr. Kimble’s hands had the victim’s blood on them. But no bruising, or bites, or scratches. I started to wonder if these two pairs of hands could have been in the same fight. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So my mind went somewhere new. If Mr. Kimble’s family had a history of hemophilia. His father said no, and medical records support that. But there is a strain of hemophilia -- hemophilia A -- that is not hereditary, and almost unheard of, so never tested for. I couldn’t think of any other explanation. I ordered the test. (and) Mr. Kimble tested positive for hemophilia A. Prosecutor again. The humiliation upon him. BENNET (CONT’D) If his hands were the murder weapon, he would have bled profusely for a long period of time. He might have even bled to death. (and now) Mr. Kimble’s hands may have touched the victim, to aid her, as he claims, but there is no scenario in which they killed her. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 20.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There is no question in my mind that if the state of Pennsylvania executes Thomas Kimble, it will kill an innocent man. 34 INT. BENNET’S CONDO - NIGHT Bennet on the phone. After a long pause--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I told you? (a silence, then-) BENNET’S FATHER/PHONE (OVER) (simply) Have you finished your schooling? Heavy Nigerian. Weary, perhaps with the time difference.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I will have the MBA completed soon. BENNET’S FATHER/PHONE (OVER) And what are you going to do with all your degrees?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Collect knowledge. I need knowledge. To run my clinic. BENNET’S FATHER/PHONE (OVER) Your clinic again (?) (tired of this already) A clinic requires a physician.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I am a physician, papa. BENNET’S FATHER/PHONE You bury the dead.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I help families understand why people die. I help the living and the dead. (a long silence) I am very good at what I do, Papa. There is an art to what I do. (even to himself he sounds plaintive, and hates it) And now a long pause. Bennet can hear his father’s breath © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  35 36 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 21. BENNET’S FATHER/PHONE (OVER) It is time to leave the classroom, leave the books. Join the world of the living. With a wife, children. Bennet Onyemalukwube Omalu: it is time to grow up and do something-- (and the SOUND of a phone being banged down--) And our eyes follow Bennet’s to the wall. Where portraits his parents hang. His father imposing; a chieftain’s kaft His mother wrapped in loud blazing colors. Bennet carefully folds a clipping from the Pittsburgh Pos Gazette: “Saved From Execution”, and a photo of himself. Slips it into an envelope: “Chief John Donatus Omalu, 90 Secondary School Road, Enugwu-Ukwu, Nigeria”. Seals it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SCOTT, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: --and you have dominion over all. In your hand are power and might-- EXT. ST. BENEDICT’S - PITTSBURGH - DAY - ESTABLISHING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sturdy brick cathedral. Massive crucified black saint broadcasting from the belltower.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SCOTT, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: --it is yours to give greatness and strength to all-- INT. ST. BENEDICT’S - PITTSBURGH - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saturday Mass. Black and immigrant congregation of 200. O by one standing in pews, offering prayers of gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SCOTT
dialogues.text: --Our God, we give you thanks and we praise the majesty of your name.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CONGREGANT
dialogues.text: I thank you, Lord, with all my heart; in the presence of the angels to you I sing. I praise your name for your mercy and faithfulness-- Bennet STOPS. Turns toward that clarion female voice. Afr lilt. Beautiful girl. Delicate profile. Bennet stares, th © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  37 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 22. His turn. He doesn’t speak his prayer, he sings it in tha big melodic heartbreaking voice--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: On the day I cried out, you answered; you strengthened my spirit. All the kings of earth will praise you, Lord, when they hear the words of your mouth. Though I walk in the midst of dangers, you guard my life when my enemies rage. (as the congregation claps, feeding off his energy--) EXT. ST. BENEDICT’S - PITTSBURGH - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Services letting out. CONGREGANTS approach Bennet, shake hand, want to be near. PASTOR and CHURCH SECRETARY huntin for-- FATHER D’AMICO Bennet! A moment? We notice - but Bennet wouldn’t - two Steelers lapel pins his frock: “10 - Stewart” & “92 - Harrison”.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCOTT
dialogues.text: We have a new member, a young lady from Kenya. She came to us a few weeks ago. She needs our help.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Of course. How much do you need? FATHER D’AMICO She needs shelter, Bennet, until we find her something permanent.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Father. I’m studying, I work long hours. My books are everywhere--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCOTT
dialogues.text: What about that studio you sub-let? Isn’t that open now--? Points out the girl with the clarion voice. PREMA MUTISO,

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Who is she? © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 23. FATHER D’AMICO She's a nice girl, from Nairobi, went to a British school. And she wants to work. We’re letting her tidy up around the church. (Bennet silent, so--) We're asking you, because we know she'll be safe and cared for. I feel God in you, Bennet--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SCOTT
dialogues.text: You know how this congregation looks up to you. (as Bennet takes her in--) Lovely, isn’t she? (yes she is, and we find them--) EXT. ST. BENEDICT’S/EXT. BENNET’S CONDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking from the church to Bennet’s - separated by a park lot. A strip of generic faux-Americana row-houses. Bennet striding fast, slightly in front-- INT. BENNET’S CONDO - DAY Bennet shows Prema in. All she has in that small bag. The stand together in his little kitchen. Her nearness like an electrical pulse. He is awkward. She less so. Her first act is to unpack her bible. We take he in: no makeup, she is simple, clear, gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: What kind of music do you like?

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: How are you for money? (no reply) Need is not weak. Need is need. I know where you are-- (and hands her some money - which she at first refuses) For anything you might need. Clothes. (she gives him a look) You are here now. You have to be a better version of yourself. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 23A.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you don’t know what that is, pick something and fake it. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  39 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 24. She takes the money. He shows her to an autonomous effici within, “Usually sublet this out--”. shows her a door. Ha her a key--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s a lock on your door. No one can get in. You have your own bathroom-- (and hands her a key) She’s not moving. She’s looking at his crisp suit, shoes. With a look of bemusement.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: What did you pick - to fake?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: An older bald white man.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: (bemused--) Why an older bald white man?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (and gets the joke. But still-) He is the best at what he does. He is brilliant at what he does. That is why. (she’s turns, starts to go, stops, then--)

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: I was a registered nurse. At the Aga Khan Hospital, in Nairobi. (now Prema takes the keys and leaves, and--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Webster barefoot, shirtless, awash in sweat. Manic pull-ups off the piping of a fallowed iron blaster. Aircraft-carrier size mountain of steel. His biceps and shoulders jacked. Now cradling a cracked pipe. Lifting and snatching it overhead, ropy muscles taught, palms it chest level. Clea and-jerk. Then crashes the log down. And stares. Paralytic. And now © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  40 4l 42 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Webster sweating in a haze of pain. Piles of notes to sel have grown. Enough of whatever this is and reaches for th Taser. Pants already off. Eyeing the crucifix dangling-- The heads charge -- CRACK! -- he cooks his thigh. Blasted against the window. Rag-dolls to the floor. Spasming. Then all slows. All of him. Every molecule of him exhales And we cut to black. And hear a light switch click on, an we’re-

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: INT. BENNET’S CONDO - SAME Bennet finds Prema in his kitchen, “Oh, you’re in here”, a decluttered home. Chaos of books systemized by subject. He moves around her awkwardly. She more comfortable than Breakfast awaits. Local fare from “back there”. Chapati. Ugali. He stops. Because-- The microscope has been moved. From table to counter. And the TV on. Unclear to him how much he likes any of this. He eats reading a business school text. Stealing glances Prema as she moves around the table, tidying. He is about stop her, or suggest, stops himself, as-- We PUSH PAST him to TV NEWS FOOTAGE: Webster's truck.

dialogues.speaker: TV BROADCAST, (OVER)
dialogues.text: In recent years the dauntless Webster had abandoned his family, slipped into financial chaos and homelessness, -- Then the TV cuts to a HIGHLIGHT REEL of Webster in his football prime, guarding the quarterback like a Secret Service agent. And Bennet grabs the remote, shuts it off-

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t really watch TV. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  43 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 26.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Then why do you have one?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: One has a TV in this country. (then) I don’t usually eat breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: One eats breakfast in this country. (and clasps her hands in prayer) Dear God thank you for the gifts you have so graciously bestowed upon me-- Bennet, stunned, watching this, then closes his hands in prayer, as--—

dialogues.speaker: PREMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please help us to continue to be deservant of our blessings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lot jammed with trucks and vans, satellite dishes. Do REPORTERS and CAMERAMEN. Bennet’s Mercedes finds a spot on the edges of the media circus. Clueless, he heads down the ramp to the basement loading area. Where he finds Sullivan and Annie arriving. Sullivan wear his “Webster/52” Steelers jersey. Gracie’s wearing Steele gold&black strung ribbon through her hair today. In Webst honor. As they converge--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Who's Mike Webster? (Sullivan pauses, disbelief, then--)

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Greatest center to ever play the game. A true warrior.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: What’s a center?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: The big guy in the middle. They tumble inside-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 27.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: My kid plays because of that guy. He wears Webster’s number. Bennet’s eyes go to Sullivan’s jersey. To the red-white-b stars-stripes logo of the NFL. Sullivan follows his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I’m very sorry. I just don’t know who he was.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: (realizing) You don’t know football. At all.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I don’t need to know football. Now clocks Gracie’s ribbons.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: I freakin can’t believe it’s you. Now Wecht arrives, joins them.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I was put on the schedule for today. I’m on the schedule every weekend.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: (dad breaking up the kids) C'mon, c’mon-- (and then they’ re--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet, Wecht, Sullivan, Gracie and the others huddled, g around the slab.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: I’m going to have to give a statement.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Let’s just do the external. We're TIGHT ON BENNET. He’s in his bubble, reading throug the EMT report, medical records. Quick probe. General appearance. Fingernails. Scorched thighs-

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: He was Tasering himself. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 28.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: The whole town was out of work. He gave us hope when there was no hope, ya know? Bennet can see inside the mess of his mouth from here.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Full autopsy, please.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Hey c’mon there’s no need. To cut this man’s body.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I can’t figure out what went wrong.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: He died. Is what went wrong.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Look at his teeth. He was pulling them out AND SUPERGLUING THEM BACK IN. Why does an apparently wealthy favorite son of this city become self-mutilating and homeless at 50? Cardiac arrest may be how he died, but not why. A beat. They're all thinking. Wecht pulls Bennet aside.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: What he’s saying is there are times when life asks you to leave things alone, and times when you can’t.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Do you think he’d want me to leave things alone? (meaning Webster) For a moment maybe even Wecht isn’t sure.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: No, I don’t. I never leave anything alone. That’s why people hate me. Just don’t screw it up. (and leaves, and as Bennet turns to the room--)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Let’s prepare the body, please. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 28A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet - Teddy in his/our ears - at the dissection table. JUMP CUTS - the unpeeling. The washing. The crevasses, th face. Ritual beyond respectful. Almost tender. Then--

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY PENDERGRASS, (OVER)
dialogues.text: ("If You Don’t Know Me By Now”) All the things that we’ve been through/You should understand me like I understand you-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 29. Now STOP. Music stops. Bennet staring down at Webster.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (quiet, intimate) Mike, you need to help me. I know there’s something wrong. Help me tell the world what happened to you. I can’t do it alone.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: (from his desk, over paperwork) Heart. Attack. Bennet performs the Y-incision.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Bone saw please.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Heart weight 327g. Mitral I ain’t gonna do nothing to valve 10.4 cm; Aortic Valve break up our happy home/Don’t 7.1 cm; Pulmonary- get so excited-- Handing organs to Gracie one by one--

dialogues.speaker: TECH
dialogues.text: Right kidney 143g ... left If you don’t know me by kidney 158g-- now/You will never never never know me-- JUMP TO: Bennet at the dissection table. Peering down, confused. Turning what he’s holding upside down and on it side then over again. Holds it to the light. Dictating--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Regular folds of gray matter. No mush. No obvious contusions. No shrinkage or erosion from Alzheimer’ s--

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Hold up the CT again for me, please. He’s comparing what’s in his hands with the pictures. Gra holds up the MRI beside the CT.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How old are these? © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 29A.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: Six months. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 30. Bennet sets the brain down. Stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: This should be a mess. It looks completely normal.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: (paging into the records) Records say severe head aches, double vision. Voices. (Bennet looks at her) In his head. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not seeing any documented concussions. He did complain of dizziness.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: How often?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: Once. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In eighteen years of professional football. Bennet takes the file himself. Scans to the signature, te doctor: “Dr. Joseph P. Maroon.”

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Sign the certificate. Sew him up.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Let’s fix the brain.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: You know we don’t have the budget for that. Gracie glances at Sullivan. He’s standing up. 10 staff ha accumulated. Wecht reappears, but stays in b.g..

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: People do not go mad for no reason. I’m going to keep looking.

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: (and Bennet looks at hima moment, and--) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 30A.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET SULLIVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Danny, you are out of line-- You don’t speak to me like that. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 31.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET SULLIVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I am the pathologist on This is not your laboratory! duty! The pathologist of record!

dialogues.speaker: BENNET SULLIVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My hands on this body. If I And you're wrong. am wrong JI am wrong.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Not you. Me-- (loud; big; no one’s heard his voice raised before) Fix! that! brain!

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: I‘1l make sure they’re not going to pay for it.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I will write my orders for the tests I want. A long tense beat. Bennet looks for Wecht. Wecht is gone. He’s alone with Sullivan. Then--

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: You're going to pay for them yourself.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Please proceed, Gracie, thank you. (and as he exits, slipping off his smock) And proceeds up the stairs--—

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to himself; prayerful; he does that) He is a child of God, like you. You are here because other people fought your battles for you. And you are still here. (and enters--) INT. WECHT’S OFFICE - ALLEGHENY COUNTY CORONER Bennet stands in front of Wecht’s desk. Wecht, in a suit doing up a tie, reading Bennet’s test orders. (We get a glimpse at the list: Tau -- Beta-Amyloid -- TDP-43 protei Ubiquitin -- Alpha-synuclein -- silver staining -) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved. + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 31a.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: In forty years, I’ve never requested a panel of tests like this. What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: There isn’t a case, in a book or in life, where a man that healthy, went that crazy that young, with no visible abnormalities of the brain. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  47 48 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 32.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) I don’t know. What I’m looking for.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: I can tell. It’s going to cost you a fortune. (then, relenting) If you have to play hero, just make sure we both come out okay. And there it is. Bennet’s on his own. And-- INT. BENNET’S CONDO - DAY Prema at the TV. She has new clothes. Jeans, t-shirt. American. She's watching a special on Webster’s career. Narration of hand-to-hand combats UNDER an elegiac score. Studying all this. Webster. Football. America. (Domestic touches have appeared. Pillows on the couch. Flowers for the table.) Prema crosses to the refrigerator. Actual food in there n Reaches for a Tupperware. Peels the lid, and-- Inside, a bisected half brain. Gray, sinewy. Floating in pool of formalin. Label says “Michael Lewis Webster”. She glances to the TV, to A TIGHT of Webster’s face. Blac helmet. “52”. Fierce eyes behind the cage.

dialogues.speaker: DAUGHTER, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Mom, dad's sitting outside again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keana tidying her daughter’s bathroom. Pauses by a window Sees Strzelczyk sitting in the rain, in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: KEANA STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: Justin you weirdo. You keep doing that-- She heads down. Stops by the front door. Post-its on the wall: “The people are Evil. God speaks to me. He says we to get to higher ground--”

dialogues.speaker: SON
dialogues.text: (coming up behind her) Daddy made these pictures for me-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  49 50

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 33.
dialogues.text: And hands Keana a stack of crayon drawings. Dark forest. Chaotic sky. Inspired, but apocalyptic. What the fuck? An She heads out there. We STAY LONG, from the doorway, as K heads toward her husband. RECEDING IN FRAME until she get him. Their daughter steps into view, watching, as-—- She reaches him, and we don’t hear what she says, it can’ have been much. Then his massive arm lifts toward her. St He turns his head toward her. The look on his face. What screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stumbles back, what she’s seen, slipping drops like s been shot, and as she scrambles away from him, we cut to-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet at a dissection table, meticulous, measuring. Alon with a half dozen bodies waiting to be dissembled and sol Clock says 1 AM. In his ear phones--

dialogues.speaker: DONNIE MCCLURKIN/CD, (OVER)
dialogues.text: (“We Fall Down”) For a saint is just a sinner who fell down/But we couldn’t stay there/And got up-- Suddenly, Bennet shuts off the music. Turns to listen, as to someone speaking-- The bodies are dermal shells. Open eyes vacant.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I apologize. And slips the cover over the microscope. Graveyard shift waves him down.

dialogues.speaker: GRAVEYARD TECH
dialogues.text: You got something today. Left it on your desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prema sits bundled in hat and scarf. One of three passeng left (one of them asleep). Near the end of the line. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  51 52

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15
dialogues.text: EXT. STREETS AROUND BENNET’S CONDO - NIGHT
Bennet’s car turns a corner as his POV sees Prema step of the bus across the street. He pulls over, opens the passenger side door. (A lab/slid tray in the seat; he picks it up, makes room.)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (calls out to her) Hi. It’s very late--

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: I have a shift now. At a home. Changing old people. Feeding them. (and as she shrugs, it’s her work-)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Let me take you home. (and she spots the tray of slides on his lap--)

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Mike Webster. (and now we find--) INT. BENNET’S CONDO - 30 MIN LATER Bennet standing over the kitchen table. Over the microsco The Webster tray before him. Amidst his medical journals books. He’s still in his coat. Tapping the books back int place. Looks back to-- Prema. Sitting on the floor, who has turned on the TV and watching football clips on ESPN. Bennet, moderately annoy still not used to another live body in his space.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Do you need me to get you a TV for your room?

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: No, this one will be fine. The books and journals--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: You were reading these? © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved. + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, Uh huh. Nonplussed. She has one of them on her Occasionally glancing at football. This confuses him.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Prema. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: I am studying. But what she’s really doing is waiting. And giving him sp She feels his anxiety. (She feels everything about him.) anxiety is her anxiety. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 35. Now Bennet opens the sleeve o slides. Stares at the them. Focused.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nervous herself) What does Iron Mike say?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: I can’t tell what you are more afraid of. What you will find, or what you won’t. Bennet looks at her. Understands. He turns to the microscope. Wipes a slide on his sleeve. Loads it. Peers. Goes still-- His fingers calibrating the foci like pianist’s fingers, delicate multi-jointed spider legs. But he’s not seeing much. Wipes another. Loads it. Not getting anything he gets up. Stands, thinking. Sits, wipe loads another. This one particular slide. We find Prema studying Bennet now. She’s turned off the T She's waiting, as-- We're TIGHT ON BENNET’S HANDS. They are now gripping the dissection table. He has seen something. Another slide. Another. Back to the first. He stands. Sit

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Oh my god. (half standing now) Oh my god what is this? What the hell is this? (then) This is the brain of an 85-year old.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Iron Mike was 50. Please, can I see?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (loads a different slide and steps aside--) This is what your brain looks like-- (she puts her face to the microscope and sees--) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 35A. A white snowy field. PUSH IN CLOSER: shapes appear. Cells neurons. Faint, clean, pristine. Like snowflakes. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  53 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 36. BENNET (CONT’D) This is Mike Webster. (loads the other, and--) We see ugly reddish-brown splotches bleeding across the pristine snow-field, drowning the snowflakes alive.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That brown stuff is tau. It’s a protein that moves in clumps called neurofibrillary tangles. The tangles strangle the neurons from inside out. (how to explain) Think of it like pouring wet concrete down kitchen pipes. That's what it does in the brain. Chokes it.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: What does that do?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: It turns you into someone else. Someone you don’t know. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’ve never seen a brain like this in a man this young. I’ve never heard of a brain this damaged in any man. Bennet goes to the fridge. Pulls the container of brain. half loaf left. As he cuts a thin slice--

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Testing it again. I have to be sure. I have to be completely sure--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISSOLVES, starting in-- BENNET’S CONDO - ACCELERATED TIME With Bennet bent over books and journals which grow and change. Bennet doesn’t move, as “Bennet” returns with ano box. Then two more. Books and journals multiplying. “Multiple traumatic cerebral hemorrhages, 1924” -- “Observations on the pathology of insidious dementia following head injury, 1959”-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 36A. The sun sinks. The moon moves across the sky. The sun ris Bennet still doesn’t move, staring at pages. Now looks up to-- CHRIS BERMAN’S VOICE (OVER) (play-by-play growl) Okay, your turn, Tom Jackson! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  54 55 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 37.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS BERMAN'S VOICE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Who’s gonna get JACKED UP tonight?! (and now WE’RE WATCHING--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet before his TV: HOST CHRIS BERMAN and his chorus of three retired PLAYERS. Berman points to former Bronco linebacker TOM JACKSON.

dialogues.speaker: TOM JACKSON
dialogues.text: Well, somebody’s going to get jacked up tonight! (and now we PUSH THROUGH TV and we're 4-walling--) The animated intro to the segment: “ESPN’S JACKED UP! ... brought to you by Texas Instruments”. Now we’re--

dialogues.speaker: TOM JACKSON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Rams - Chargers. Quarterback Mark Bulger is going to deliver the ball to Tony Fisher-- Rams’ RECEIVER looks back for the ball, is totally decima by a forearm shiver to the head. The crowd goes nuts--

dialogues.speaker: TOM JACKSON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Donnie Edwards just LEVELS him--! And the head in SLO-MO seems to break off at the neck.

dialogues.speaker: TOM JACKSON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: (call--) (--response) Tony Fisher got-- JACKED! UP! (and--) (now BACK TO--) BENNET’S CONDO. PREMA’S POV OF BENNET AT THE MICROSCOPE Slides stacked in groupings: Beta-A4 amyloid peptide; CD- GFAP; Luxol-Fast Blue; Tau. Bennet loads slide after slid COACH’S VOICE (PRE-LAP) (screaming! ) Only way to get that player's hands off you is grab him by the throat and squeeze - choke him til shit runs down his leg! (and now cut to a--) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  56 57 58 59 60 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on a pair of players. The bigger of the two stabbin jabbing RAMMING his palm into the throat of the other, gripping, release, grip, release, over and over until the other goes down and lies broken. Now we-- Bennet slips into our extreme f.g., taking this in, then turning, and the field morphs and we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching fifty 14-year olds doing wind-sprints. Joyful. They're ribbing each other. Boys. Then. Whistle blows. An every player unleashes on someone anyone to hit/spear wit the crowns of their helmets. CRACK! CRACK! CRACK! Like gunshots echoing from all corners. Now-- BACK IN BENNET’S LIVING ROOM - TIGHTER ON THE TV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet watching tape of a pro training camp. Lumbering lineman running laterally to stretch a play. Linebacker spears helmet into face, to crack jaw and neck. And back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s been 60 seconds. The kids still randomly head-rammin few of them here and there staggering off. Now back to-- THE LIBRARY THAT IS NOW BENNET’S CONDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every surface stacked with books, journals. “Traumatic cerebral hemorrhage. Neurology and Psychiatry, 1929.” Bennet’s midnight-to-dawn sessions INTERCUT with Prema watching NFL games. Steelers, Raiders, Dolphins. CRACK! Bennet glancing only at the SOUND of helmets crashing. Prema studying the game, the strategy. The quarterbacks scrambling for their lives, slipping from the clutches of pursuers, launching passes that float impossibly into the hands of full-sprint receivers 50 yards away.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: (to Bennet somewhere else in the condo) Oh wow-- (new fan; as she’s clearing the table) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  61 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 39.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should watch this, Bennet. (as he lifts his head to-) BIG POWER RUNNING BACK (ND college) spins sliding to dayl outrunning an entire defense as if they are standing stil

dialogues.speaker: PREMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s actually really beautiful! Bennet! Of crisp sunny days and long shadows and end-zone glory. Victory dances. Cheerleaders. Spectacle. Of big men wrestling in the mud, reaching down to pull up comrades. Of stands boiling with ecstasy. There’s all that too. And we’re back in love with the gam

dialogues.speaker: PREMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tommy Maddox is the most underrated quarterback in the League! (because she’s watching) The TV, where the Steelers are winning a Wild Card Playof game against the Browns 36 - 33. “No time outs, they have time outs left!” And Prema is hooked. While Bennet, insid his head, goes-- BENNET’S POV/WHAT HE'S SEEING An ANIMATION OF the deceleration of a football head. Helm colliding with a knee. Head halted abruptly. But the brai floating in fluid, keeps going, smashing into the inner skull, as a rubber ball might when smashed by a racquet. And our animated head - 4-walled - morphs in Bennet’s POV into the armored and caged head of Mike Webster. He's ben over. The other 20 players vanish, and it’s just him and Bradshaw. Endless repetitions. Hut-snap. Hut-snap. It’s a kind of clinic. This is how it’s done. The two of them a single organism, and BAM! And now--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s game time, and the field is full, the stands are ful and Webster is nut-cracked between two defensive linemen. there’s Webster’s rubber-ball brain boing-boinging off th skull, skull off helmet, helmet off other helmet. And we REVERSE and we’re looking at-- Bennet. Studying the TV. Where there’s now-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  62 63 64 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eagles punter alone in backfield, about to kick. Two Jagu special team backs full-sprint from pincher angles--

dialogues.speaker: TOM JACKSON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Now I really love this one. Jorge Cordova and Brian-- The backs arrive same time. Helmets into chest and throat Punter, crushed, stiffens, as if Tasered, drops-—

dialogues.speaker: TOM JACKSON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: And Dirk Johnson-- GOT! JACKED! UP! (then back to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s been 90 seconds. Bennet is simply walking away as th turf is like a battlefield of the exhausted. THIS WHOLE SEQUENCE STOPS NOW. We slow. We’re--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clock says 4AM. We’re DOLLYING SLOW THROUGH the autopsy chamber. Silhouettes of fresh bodies on the slabs. Light spills out of the lab. We follow it to Bennet at a significantly bigger microscope than he has. Rubbing the of his neck. Prema has put a couple chairs together and is asleep unde blanket, between Bennet and the corpses. Keeping guard. Against everything. Her really astounding beauty. Now TILT UP to Bennet standing over her. Really seeing he for the first time. Prema stirs. Eyes open huge dark almo right up into Bennet’s face. He is clear-headed, suddenly As if she’s heard something. Her eyes shift to a cadaver. perfect stillness.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: That is not who they are. (then; his expression) I think I found a disease no one has ever seen. Not once. Not ever.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Isn’t that good? © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  65 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 41.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: It’s a terrible disease.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: So what do you do? (So what does one do in this country when one discovers a terrible disease.)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I have to be sure. (but then--) O.S., the SOUND of a door opening. Footsteps approach. Th fluorescent lights bounce on in the autopsy chamber. REVEALING the row of dead faces, and--

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Who's back there? (Bennet comes out) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Working.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: You’re not on the schedule.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I’m using personal time. I needed the microscope.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: In here is county time. Prema appears. Sullivan leers. Her clothes. Her unkempt h He spots the blanket on the chair. SULLIVAN (CONT’D) You banging prostitutes in here, Omalu? Bennet takes three big steps toward Sullivan. Fists clenc Prema - “Don’t” - slides between them, shoves Bennet back Sullivan walks away-- SULLIVAN (CONT’D) They deport you weirdos for sick shit like that. And now we rise up to--

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  66 67 68 69 70 71 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 42.

dialogues.speaker: SOARING GIANT BLACK ST. BENEDICT
dialogues.text: Atop St. Benedict’s. Arms spread out over Pittsburgh. Now across the river to--

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: BIRD’S-EYE POV of the sprawling 10-story complex. Abuttin Pitt’s Coliseum-like football stadium. The dual-chambered heart of the sprawling city of higher learning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet cradles the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet walks an endless hallway with a hundred doors, whe DR. RON HAMILTON - 49, academic, cropped beard - is watch him approach from his office doorway - “Chairman, Neuropathology Program, Univ. of Pittsburgh Medical Schoo

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: What did you bring me?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I need you to look at this cold. (as they go into--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And leads Bennet into his office, digging out the slides. Bennet steps to the window, looks down on massive Heinz Field.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Bennet. Relax. I can hear you breathing. (another look, then--) Hamilton slowly lifts his head. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a really really terrible brain. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  72 73 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 43. And we SLAM to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Office of “Dr. Steven DeKosky, Chairman, Dept of Neurolog Out strides DEKOSKY, a fit 55. Pissed-off to be interrupt And back to--

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Ever met the great man before? (Bennet shakes, No) Tough. One of the top brain guys in the world. Expect two minutes tops. DeKosky blows in. Gives Hamilton a “this better be good” look.

dialogues.speaker: DEKOSKY
dialogues.text: That him? (Hamilton nods) So you’re our prize graduate. And crosses straight to the microscope. Great focus, long moment of this. Then-- It’s very obvious. And he faces them. In the presence of something monumental and knows it.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Tell him.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: That is Mike Webster. The Pittsburgh Steeler--

dialogues.speaker: DEKOSKY
dialogues.text: (get to the point) I know who Mike Webster is.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Steve. He was fifty. (and that’s the point and-) DeKosky looks to the window, mentally shuffling through h decades of study, toil, research. The tens of thousands o hours. Then reaches for the phone-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: DEKOSKY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Cancel the rest of my morning-- (hangs up; then) You have my attention. Hamilton nods, Go.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Diving birds hit the sea at 200 MPH, generating 1,000 g-force at impact. Each peck of a woodpeckers produces a g-force of a thousand. 12,000 pecks a day, 85-million times over their lifetimes. Big- horned sheep-- (DeKosky gives Hamilton an impatient look)

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Bennet-—

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: All these animals have shock absorbers built into their bodies. The woodpecker’s tongue comes out the back of the mouth through the nostril and goes around the top of its head. Basically, it’s one big safety belt for the brain. (then) Humans? Not one piece of our anatomy protects us from those kinds of collisions. A human being will get concussed at 80 g’s. The average head-to-head contact on a football field? 120 g's. God did not intend for us to play football.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Let’s keep God out of this. And Bennet goes to a white board and draws the S’s/O’s coach's diagram of football squads. Offense. Defense. The backs. The quarterback. And circles the center-- HAMILTON (CONT’D) BENNET What’s the ‘S’? The Steelers.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON DEKOSKY
dialogues.text: The ‘O’s--? The ‘others’. Obviously.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: The others, yes. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 45.

dialogues.speaker: DEKOSKY
dialogues.text: Do you even watch football?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Not at all-- (back to the board) But I studied Mike Webster’s position. The one int he middle. The most violent on the field. The slaps and the choking, the head as a weapon on every play of every game, of every practice. From the time he was a boy, then a college man, through a professional career. The thousands and thousands of hits that weren’t concussions. Now circles the wide-outs, running backs and safeties-- BENNET (CONT’D) But these? They are the fastest.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Their speed multiplied by the speed of the men who hit them, and the trajectories at which they hit them, the g-force created - the same as getting hit on the head with a sledgehammer --

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Slow down. The brain. Get to the brain part--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (distinctly not slowing) Mike Webster played eighteen years of professional football. 90- thousand blows to the head during just his professional career, by my calculation. (and now--) All this triggered a cascading series of neurological events that unleashed killer protein upon Mike Webster’s brain. The tangles invading and then strangling his mind from the inside out. Leaving him unrecognizable, even to himself. And before you ask me why it’s not the same as boxers-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 46.

dialogues.speaker: DEKOSKY BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dementia pugilistica-- Why it is not the same is that when a boxer receives this kind of blow, it is once in a very long while. Because he goes down and he often does not get up, and the fight is over. It is not over and over and over every day of every week, week in week out, practice or game.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know the game. I have never played the game. But I am convinced playing football killed him. (and) And there have to be others.

dialogues.speaker: DEKOSKY
dialogues.text: How can you know that?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Common sense. But they’re dead. Or lost. Like Mike Webster was lost.

dialogues.speaker: DEKOSKY
dialogues.text: I’m not interested in common sense. The only thing that interests me is science, and science is knowing.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I know from these men’s records their doctors think they have early Alzheimer’s. Which is statistically impossible. Because it isn’t Alzheimer’s. It's this. Dekosky sits.

dialogues.speaker: DEKOSKY
dialogues.text: Holy Christ.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Steve. It’s a billion-dollar finding.

dialogues.speaker: DEKOSKY
dialogues.text: I don’t like it. Actually, I hate it. But as a scientist I can’t deny it.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: We need to tell them. Now. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: The NFL? What, like call them?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DEKOSKY
dialogues.text: This is one case.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Men are dying. Right now. Someone is getting divorced. Right now. Someone is arguing. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: DEKOSKY
dialogues.text: Bennet. The only way people are taking you seriously is if you publish. Peer review. Respected medical journal.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: We'll coauthor, our names with yours.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: With all due respect, under normal circumstances, I understand there is a correct way, but--

dialogues.speaker: DEKOSKY
dialogues.text: Slow. Down. Bennet. (then) I will back you up, but we do this the right way. Okay, a breath, gets it--

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: And name this. You’re going to have to give this a name.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: INT. BENNET’S CONDO - THAT NIGHT As Bennet slips past Prema’s little efficiency, the door opens. Prema steps out. New dress. Flower in her hair.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (awkward) I thought you were asleep. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  76 77 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 48.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: How could I sleep? Did they agree? What it is? He’s overwhelmed. Can only nod, Yes, they understood.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET PREMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They are going to publish They? With you? with me.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET PREMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A medical journal-- With you? And touches his arm. So happy for him she can cry. (And m she does, a little.)

dialogues.speaker: PREMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's so great. Congratulations--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: You are going somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Yes, with you. To celebrate. And under a PRE-LAP throb of dance music, taking in the f breadth of this woman, perhaps for the first time, then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowded, loud, sexy. Bennet and Prema awkward by the spea in the strobing light. Bennet can’t connect to the music. Doesn't really know what to do with her there.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: You don’t dance, do you? (he shakes, No, then--) She's dragging him onto the floor. Circles him, gorgeous fluid dancer and is all about bringing him to life. She i contagious Bennet slowly forgets all the things that keep from doing more than listen. Until it’s the other way aro and he’s putting it out, and moving. Then they’re back in INT. HALLWAY - BENNET’S CONDO - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're passing her door on the way to his. They stop. He unsure. She’s not. He says, “Goodnight”. She reaches, get his hand, pulls him in. And on her toes, kisses his cheek And that lingers. And then he’s taking her face in his ha and bringing it to his. And she’s pushing him into his ro Then it’s-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

Bennet parks his Mercedes. A second one slides next to hi Identical except in color. This one silver. Wecht gets ou Like the suits, the cars are the same. Wecht carrying two coffees, two brown bags. Then--

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: (hands Bennet a coffee, a bag, and as they walk around to the front--) It’s weird to bring women into a morgue at night.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: She’s a friend.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: You don’t have friends.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I have a friend now.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Sullivan made a formal complaint against you with the county.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I was working on Webster.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: I know. I took care of it. What’s Webster cost you, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Twenty-thousand dollars. (then) I save. Everything.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: How unAmerican. (then, after a beat) Apparently it’s been worth it. Ron Hamilton called. Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy. Has a nice ring to it. Why didn’t you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I wasn’t going around you. I need someone with fresh eyes. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 49a, BENNET (CONT'D) Someone who didn’t want it to be true or not true. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 50.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: I don’t like it. But it was the right thing to do. This may come as a surprise, but I’ll never be the one you have to worry about. So what’s next?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Publish. DeKosky wants to coauthor.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: DeKosky, and--?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Cyril Wecht.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: I’m proud of you, kid. (compares the two cars) Should've gotten the silver. Blue shows the dirt. (and heads in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The faces are looking AT CAMERA. Watching the TV behind u Nowhere to move. Nothing else to see or hear. WE FIND BENNET & PREMA in that crowd. Hot wings and nacho (Prema has brought along two or three FRIENDS from church And we're watching them watching, and boarding the ride. it’s loud and really fucking joyful. The game is a drug, good healthy one, and we’re rollercoasting triumph and de and individual acts of heroism. What is absolutely and undeniably GREAT about this game. And-- Bennet - this moment - is just one of them. Riding the ri But ONE OF THEM. An AMERICAN. He’s touching and being touched. High-fiving and being high-fived. And then CAMERA TWEAKS past them-- To a face deep in the crowd: Mike Webster, leaning agains the bar, watching his old team. And Bennet is reminded. O everything. Now cut to another screen showing the Steeler game-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  79 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 50A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where, in a SINGLE TRACKING SHOT, we pass Keana and the k watching in Their Man’s “#73” Steelers jersey. CAMERA PUL out of the living room, game and kids receding, as we PUS © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 51. Into the bedroom. Where we FIND Strzelczyk. Heavier, disheveled. Lips moving in mute dialog. Eyes clock his guitar. Grabs it, wields it like a baseball bat. CAMERA FOLLOWS BEHIND him downstairs, back into the living room-

dialogues.speaker: KEANA STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: Justin, what the hell are you doing? Are you serious? Justin STOP! what is wrong with you WHAT

dialogues.speaker: STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: I’m getting messages. Evil Ones. Talking talking talking!

dialogues.speaker: KEANA STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: Are you FREAKIN SERIOUS RIGHT NOW?! Now explosion of wood and glass as he smashes the guitar the wall. KEANA STRZELCZYK (CONT’D) (weeping now; terrified) Oh my god baby what are they saying, baby, please tell me what the voices are saying--

dialogues.speaker: STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: Kill you! (and now--)

dialogues.speaker: STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: I don’t know what I’m doing! I don’t know what’s happening to me!? Strzelczyk’s looking straight into his little boy’s stric face. Terrified by the terror in his kid. The part of him that knows drags the other part of him out.

dialogues.speaker: KEANA STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: (cuddling the kids) Baby shh I need you to call 911 right now for me baby and tell them that daddy is in pain and to come here right away baby, shh, it’s going to be okay-- And bolting out the door after Strzelczyk-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  80 81

dialogues.speaker: SON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (into phone) My daddy’s Justin Strzelczyk the football player, WHAT IS HAPPENING

dialogues.speaker: PLEASE HURRY UP
dialogues.text: And now PRE-LAPPING sirens -- engines gunning -- police scanners toning, urgent ... now we’re-- INT. STRZELCZYK’S TRUCK Eyes in the rear-view. In conversation with someone insid his face. “Webby, what did we do?” Hanging from the mirror: two pairs of baby shoes. His eye see those, calm. Now. A moment of repose. Searches the mirror. There you are. He’s crying. He knows what he need do. Hands gripping the wheel sure as ever. CUT TO BLACK. Horns wailing--

dialogues.speaker: BROADCAST/TV, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: - this is live footage of the aftermath of a horrific head-on collision on the New York Thruway - (and up to--)

dialogues.speaker: VAST SMOLDERING DEBRIS FIELD
dialogues.text: The two trucks mere piles of powder. Body bag in the gras

dialogues.speaker: BROADCAST/TV, (OVER)
dialogues.text: - KDKA has learned that one of the drivers was retired Pittsburgh Steeler offensive star Justin Strzelczyk, who led police on a forty-mile high-speed pursuit - (fades out as--) PULL BACK TO REVEAL Julian Bailes watching this on his kitchen TV, and we cut to and find--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet standing in the rain/snow, watching the university team finish up practice. A mud bowl. Burpies. Windsprints Everyone's filthy. Pigs in shit. Looks fun. End whistle, player breaks away. Stampeding at us. Bennet starts to la This is AMOBI OKOYE, 19 and enormous: 6'2”/300. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 53.

dialogues.speaker: OKOYE
