dialogues.text: Bennet!? Nwokem kedu?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (big laughter) You giant American baby! You look like a giant American dirty baby! Kedu ka mma-mma gi meah? BENNET (CONT’D) OKOYE O noh na nke Ifeoma? Eeah. Maalu na oge obuna icho ibia, anom mia, oge obuna. And big laughter. In his native tongue, and with his cous he is more the man of where he comes from. Bigger.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (me and the giant--) They sent us both to America. To see which one survives. The David and the Goliath! (and his hands say who is who, and then--)

dialogues.speaker: OKOYE
dialogues.text: You are just a professional student! Do you have time for any other thing?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Superman! Now Amobi realizes how far Bennet’s come. Confused.

dialogues.speaker: OKOYE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, my cousin? Did somebody die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet and Amobi. Coffee. Untouched. The glee has gone. Bennet has told him.

dialogues.speaker: OKOYE
dialogues.text: What are the chances?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: For your position? They’re good.

dialogues.speaker: OKOYE
dialogues.text: You're not even sure of this thing. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 54.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: You'll forget your own name. Amobi Okoye. Can you imagine not knowing that?

dialogues.speaker: OKOYE
dialogues.text: Who imagines that?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: You are part of me. I watched you be born. I am asking you. Stop.

dialogues.speaker: OKOYE
dialogues.text: I step on the field I always know I can be hurt. More than hurt-- (and snaps his fingers. Like that.) Maybe I play two years then I’m out. You know what’s next? Most of them get fat, bankrupt. They sell cars, insurance (sneakers), I don’t know what they do. This is my time before that time. (then the crux of it, the arrogance returns) They are saying I will be drafted first. The youngest player ever drafted into the NFL. I will cash a check for millions of dollars. Millions just for saying yes.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: God didn’t put anyone on earth to cash a check.

dialogues.speaker: OKOYE
dialogues.text: Look where I am, Cousin. Look what I am. I’m not going to let anyone take this from me now. Daalu nwanem, agam akpo gi mgbe nmaah abia. And as we HOLD on Bennet, we cut to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet WALKING STRAIGHT INTO CAMERA, up the hallway. Peel gloves, lab coat. (In b.g., the slabs, a pair of upturned feet.) The Techs - Sullivan - no one’s saying a thing. And into- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  83 85 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 55. His shitbox office. Where a warm bottle of cheap champagn sits on his desk, with a copy of Neurosurgery Journal. A it stuck to the neck says: “Enjoy with your new friend. B Cyril.” INT. BENNET’S CONDO - AFTERNOON Bennet enters with the bottle, to find Prema studying Bennet’s article. With a dictionary. He watches her until feels him and looks up. Tears in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: This is very amazing. Now what happens?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (nervous to say it) I called them.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Who did you call?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: The National Football League.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I said I'd be happy to come in and discuss it.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: (on alert) What did they say?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: They said they’d get back to me. (and a hard cut to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN carrying a stack of magazines enters a 60-story gla office tower, in the heart of midtown, between two logos: Credit Suisse, and the NFL’s shield. And into-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  86 87 84 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracking the man - CHRISTOPHER JONES, 43, African America through a massive office, through the quiet confidence of major multinational corporation. To his executive suite. (There are Harvard undergraduate and law diplomas.) Jones picks Neurosurgery off the top, opens it to the CTE article, and, into the intercom--

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Get me Elliot Pellman. INT. DOCTOR’S PRIVATE OFFICE - LONG ISLAND - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. ELLIOT PELLMAN is absorbed in Neurosurgery. He's 48, shlubby, a bad comb-over. Surrounded by memorabilia for t NFL’s New York Jets and the NY Islanders hockey team.

dialogues.speaker: PELLMAN
dialogues.text: (picks up the phone) I’m just looking at it.

dialogues.speaker: JONES/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Anything to be concerned about?

dialogues.speaker: PELLMAN
dialogues.text: This Omalu looks like a nobody. But let me get into it. (and a hard cut to--) INT. KITCHEN - BAILES’ HOME - MORNING/SIMULTANEOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bailes at the kitchen table in sweatpants. Breakfast. Bailes’s wife, COLLEEN, 40, slips her arms around him. Bailes reading a copy of Neurosurgery Journal (open to “Chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) in a National Football League player” ... Omalu, DeKosky, Hamilton, Wec

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN BAILES
dialogues.text: What are you reading?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: It’s about Mike.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN BAILES
dialogues.text: I miss Mike. (brain scans) Oh god I can’t look at that. (Bailes rubbing his face; (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 57.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN BAILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: looking into the middle distance, doing the math) Julian, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: How could I have missed this?

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN BAILES
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: If this is really true, it’s the end of football. (and cut to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet, Sullivan, Gracie stand over 300-lbs. of heavily muscled death. Black. No wounds, no blood.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: (looking at the face; grief- stricken) Well now, Terry. Ya wonder where are they now. Now we know. (for Bennet) Terry Long. Pittsburgh Steelers.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: (reading hospital report) Who drank a gallon of antifreeze. That’s not how I’d do it.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: I guess these guys only die when you're working--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: What other problems did he have?

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Who cares?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: Arrested a few times. (looking at the report) Fraud. Federal theft. And wow. Arrested a lot.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: I know what you're doing. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  89 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 58.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Drinking antifreeze is the work of a lunatic mind. (then) What position? What position did he play?

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Offensive line.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET SULLIVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Same as Mike Webster. Webby was a center. Terry played right guard.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (the records) No recorded concussions. Nine years of professional football. As an offensive guard. (then) I need a full autopsy. Same tests as Webster.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: You're paying for that, too.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Yes, Daniel. I’m paying for that, too. (Bennet doesn’t even hear it, his eyes already focused on--) Joseph Maroon-- The signature on Long’s records: Joseph Maroon. And now c to-- JOE MAROON’S COMPUTER IMAGE SMILING AT US, TRIM, TAN,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull back to REVEAL we’re in Bennet’s little shitbox offi at the Coroner’s. He’s at his computer. Before him, the website www. josephmaroon.com, the personal site for the Steelers’ team doctor. Chief neuro-surgeon of the NFL. Th country’s premiere specialist in neurosurgery and sports medicine.” Bright pastel design, mentorships on longevity healthy living. The whole thing like an ad for toothpaste Viagra. All white, now-- PULL BACK again. And our view has become a cottony field. faint outline of snowflake-like brain cells. Then, from t corner, the seepage of angry rust-brown blood. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  90 91 92 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 59. Tau protein tangles. Seeping and strangling everything in their path. PULL BACK FULL TO REVEAL--—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet. It’s late. The only other living thing in the building is Prema. In a chair now, by the door, reading w a flashlight. Bennet’s seen enough. Clicks off the table lamp. Just sit slumped in the glow of the instruments and exit signs. Then, in PRE-LAP, a phone rings, and we cut to--

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: INT. BENNET’S CONDO - MORNING Prema picks up the phone, “Hello?”. Hands to Bennet. And

dialogues.speaker: MAN/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Bennet Omalu?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Bennet Omalu.

dialogues.speaker: MAN/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Listen to me. Football has the best doctors money can buy, and they’re saying pro football players do not get brain damage. At all. And people who care about this stuff are supposed to take your word for it? Mike Webster was a pill-popping drunk. And you’re an under-educated hack. And you’re done, game over. And looks up at Prema. The line is already dead. He hangs

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) I think they called back.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Did he really say you're under- educated? Have they seen your resume? © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 60. 93 INT. WECHT’S OFFICE - ALLEGHENY COUNTY CORONER - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet, Wecht, Hamilton.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Well, I got calls, too. The National Football League owns neuroscience. Who knew?

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: (reading from a letter) “Serious misinterpretation”. “Failure to find”. “Absence of clinical information”. (looks to Wecht, ‘help?’) Bennet’s at the window. In his hand, an envelope. Wecht a Hamilton have one too.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: What do they want?

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Your head on a spike.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: They want you to retract your findings.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I don’t know what that means.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: It means saying you made it all up.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (confused) Made it up??

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: They're accusing you of fraud--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (and now totally fucking confused) Fraud?? What are they talking about?? I’m so careful. I slaved over this--

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Your reputation will be destroyed. You won’t be able to work. Anywhere. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 61. Good.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT BENNET
dialogues.text: Good! ?

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: They're terrified of you.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I have to work! My visa depends on it.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Well, what the hell did you think they were going to say, ‘Thank you'?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Yes! I thought they’d be grateful!

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: What the hell for?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: For being told. For knowing. Bennet paces to the window, confused.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: I get it. You think you’re being a good American. (and looks at him; pride and sadness) Listen to me. The city of Pittsburgh shelled out 233-million dollars to help build its beloved Steelers a glorious new stadium while it was closing schools and raising taxes. (and snatches the envelope out of Bennet’s hand and waves it in his face) These are not people who want to change the world. (now waves Bennet’s article) And this isn’t some quaint academic discovery stuck in the back of an obscure medical journal. Bennet Omalu is going to war with the manufacturer of a product that twenty-million Americans crave every Sunday the way they crave water! The NFL owns a day of the week! They’re very big! © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  94

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15
dialogues.text: Pause. A long pause. 62. Bennet turns back to the window, staring out over the car of lights. And the bridges. And the river. And Heinz Field.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: A pathologist determines cause of death, not discover disease. They'll say Bennet’s in over his head, and they’1ll be right.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Yeah well the world only gets changed by people who are over their heads ignoring people who say they’re in over their heads. (but then--) Bennet turns back from the window. Face set.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Terry Long. (beat; what?) The tests came back today. Terry Long is positive. Football gave him CTE. CTE told his brain to drink a gallon of antifreeze. And then he died. (then) I told you. There were going to be more. (after a pause--)

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: You've done great work. No one’s going to blame you if you stopped here. But I’d be lying to you if I didn’t tell you how important your next move is. Pause. Wecht is taking in Bennet, waiting. Bennet and Wec HOLD a look, then Wecht sees it in Bennet’s face--

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: No one’s stopping anything. INT./EXT. BENNET’S CONDO - DAY Prema grabs her coat and purse to go out. Pauses by the window. Where she sees Bennet sitting in his car in the parking lot, deep in thought. And we cut to-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  Ag94 95 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 63. Her outside, bundling up, crossing to him. She gets in-- INT. BENNET’S CAR - DAY Prema waits for Bennet to say something. He doesn’t. She a hand on his arm, Do you want to talk. He doesn’t move. pulls away--

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Then do you mind just taking me to Western Union? I need to wire money to my mother.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (still in his reverie) Do you send her everything?

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Not everything.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: What you make is also for you.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: So is this. And that gets his attention. He turns to look at her. Tak her in, this selfless woman. And now they’re--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet and Prema stand by the river, looking north and so past the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: When I was a boy, in Nigeria, heaven was here. (and holds his hand over his head) And America was here-- (just below) It was the place where God sent all his favorite people. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to America because I thought here you could do anything, be anything. Americans were the manifestation of what God wanted all of us to be. (then) But Mike Webster goes mad and nobody asks why. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 64.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They make fun of him. And now they want to pretend this disease doesn’t exist? They want to bury me? It’s offensive. I’m offended. I’m the wrong person to have discovered this. A quiet. Then. A clarity and confidence bigger than she i

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: There is no coincidence in this world. Tell me. What is the statistical probability that you, not just a doctor, but Bennet Omalu, came to America, end up here, this rusty place, for you alone to be the one to see this? (long pause) When I arrived, in New York, I was attacked-- (and stops)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Something that is better left unsaid. But that man almost broke me. I wanted to give up, and go back. But I knew God, I decided to trust his wisdom. (and--) And now I am looking at this man, an Omalu Onyemalukube. Your name. It means, If you know, you must come forth and speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Bennet metabolizing what she’d just told him. Then

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: How did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: I called your father. (Bennet surprised) He was pleased to hear from me.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Cyril said if I speak it could be dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: If you don’t speak for the dead, who will? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  96 97 98 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 65.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are of the Igbo tribe, Bennet. Igbo man is bold and cannot be silenced. When you have the truth, the thing you are told you cannot do is the thing you must do. Embrace that, and nothing created by God can bring you down. (long beat; then) I would do anything to support that kind of man. On Bennet’s face now: not love but conviction. And he surprises himself, by spontaneously embracing her. Holds her. As if to keep her from floating away from him now. ( maybe clinging to keep himself from sinking.) And now off his face, we cut to--

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: ENTRY SIGN “WELCOME TO MOON TOWNSHIP” PULL BACK TO REVEAL a Rockwellian Americana. Partially- birthed spread of faux McMansions. Foundations waiting fo homes. Light mottled through the trees reflects off the windows Bennet’s car. As his Mercedes pulls past the sign. Their faces in and out of light and shadow. Winding to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet pulls over at a virgin half-acre. Houses around it to the studs. Some are done. A handful occupied. 0O.S. WH of aircraft - jet-wash - floating in. Slow parade of plan We're near the airport, under the flight path. Bennet walks Prema onto the ground. She spins, wondering where she’s supposed to look.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: This is my dream. The schools are good. (then) And you are good, Prema. You are the only thing in my life that is not my work that I can understand. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  99 100 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 66.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) I am sure you see good in me.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: I see good in you, Bennet. I see all that you are.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I want to marry you. (then) We can fall in love.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: If you want to marry me, I will marry you.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: That’s good. Because I already put down the payment. I’ve saved all my money. And now bought this for you. What happens next is not quite a hug. And not quite a han shake. An awkward transactional embrace. Now cut to--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET/CAMERA MONITOR
dialogues.text: By the time he committed suicide, Terry Long's brain was ruined. People with CTE suffer from depression, which can lead to suicide attempts. Terry Long committed suicide due to CTE, which was a result of his long-term play. The NFL is in denial-- (now we go to the live version--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet giving a news conference. Wecht and Hamilton flank him. The cameras are mostly local news. We see Prema in t b.g. under an awning, because-- It’s raining. But the crowd is still healthy.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: It is probable that a big percentage of professional football players have or will develop CTE, and will die of it. Maybe even most of them. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on these words, we're FINDING faces in the crowd. Mos are distracted by the rain to take it all in. But one - a YOUNG REPORTER in his 30's, leaning practically falling forward to hear everything--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I suspect we will also start finding it in and out of sports, in all activities where head impact happens--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG REPORTER
dialogues.text: (stunned) Holy shit. Rain picking up. Cameramen are packing.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: This might explain all kinds of dysfunctional behavior. Why good people go bad--

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Any questions? (not one, because--) The news guys can’t get back to their trucks fast enough. kind of anti-climactic, as Bennet & Wecht make their way to Prema-- WECHT (CONT’D) No ignoring that. You’re going to be an American hero.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: But I am not an American.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Even better. That’s so fucking American. As Wecht keeps moving Bennet stops before Prema. On his f a light, a look of mission. And now, in PRE-LAP, we HEAR--

dialogues.speaker: PREMA, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: (above the others) My soul proclaims the greatness of the Lord; my spirit rejoices in God my savior. For he has looked upon his handmaid's lowliness; behold, from now on will all ages call me blessed--! © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  101 102 103 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 68.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: INT. ST. BENEDICT’S - PITTSBURGH - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Congregation flooding the aisles. Heading out. Prema holds Bennet’s hand as they exit. Prema brings Bennet’s h to her forehead, like a sacrament. We clock an engagement ring. Bennet’s big easy smile around them. But he can’t get traction - no one suddenly seems to be acknowledging them As the congregation pours out, Father D’Amico with a word everyone. Different Steelers lapel pins: “36-Bettis” & “5 Farrior”. As Bennet and Prema head past-- FATHER D’AMICO Football and Dr. Bennet Omalu. Who knew? (his smile - what is its quality?) We saw you on the news. Quite a splash.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: It isn’t about football, Father. Mrs. Scott has discreetly come up alongside, with her

dialogues.speaker: MR. SCOTT
dialogues.text: Well, then it’s a question, on the one hand, of the reputation of certain men, and something that brings our community - your community - together. That gives this city, and other cities, a thing to face us all in the same direction. And, on the other hand, I suppose, if it’s really true, this so-called disease. (a quiet falls, then--) FATHER D’AMICO Well, bless you both. And they stand there alone and untouched. And as they tur leave-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  104

dialogues.speaker: AUTHORITATIVE VOICE/TV, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: There is no so-called concussion “problem” in the NFL-- (and cut to)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third-hand furniture. Three Techs lounging around the TV. Chyron says: “NFL Commissioner Paul Tagliabue and Dr. Ell Pellman, Director of the NFL Medical Committee”. On his f mild amusement. Across from them, SPORTS WRITER/PERSONALI

dialogues.speaker: PELLMAN/TV
dialogues.text: NFL football players are less vulnerable to concussions and post- concussion syndrome any more than the general population. In fact, professional football players knocked unconscious can be returned to play on the same day of their injury without significant risk. Look, there’s no magic number for how many concussions is too many concussions. Concussions are just an occupational risk.

dialogues.speaker: TAGLIABUE/TV
dialogues.text: Concussions, I think, is one of these pack journalism issues, frankly. The problem is it’s a journalist issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we find Bennet eating alone in a crappy little Chines joint. Next to under-oxygenated fish drifting in a foggy tank. The TV behind the bar is on, sounds low, midday new As Bennet looks up and sees a clip of a 60-Minutes-style interview on TV--

dialogues.speaker: SPORTS PERSONALITY/TV
dialogues.text: So where's the science coming from? (and now INTERCUTTING from yet another interview-) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  105 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 70.

dialogues.speaker: PELLMAN/TV
dialogues.text: From nowhere. Let’s be honest. Whatever this Omalu wants his science to say, NFL players are the biggest, strongest, toughest men in the world. They have evolved to a state where their brains are actually less susceptible to injury. I actually send veterans back in more quickly than rookies. They know how to unscramble their brains a little faster. A rookie won't know what's happened to him and will be a little panicky. The veterans expect the hits. They want the hits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet can’t believe what he just heard, maybe smiles a little, notes LUNCHERS paying attention to all that. On t faces: pensive appreciation, agreement. Bennet sobers. Pu away his untouched meal. Then-- As we start to HEAR a phone RINGING in PRE-LAP, we’re-- INT. BENNET’S CONDO - THAT DAY And Bennet - just home - coat still on, leaning against t kitchen table. The home phone ringing as--

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: (reading from the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette) “--Dr. Maroon, who is also vice chairman of the neurosurgery department at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, said, of Omalu’s CTE diagnoses, that it was “fallacious reasoning.” (and looks to the phone, keeps going) “To go back and say Long was depressed from playing in the NFL and that led to his death 14 years later I think is purely speculative.” (and looks up from the paper, at her man--) It’s not easy to get what you want. Bennet finally picks up the phone-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 70A.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: (local, messy, possibly drunk) This Omalu? © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  106 107 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 71.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Bennet Omalu--

dialogues.speaker: VOICE/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: I just want to tell you that this is none of your goddamn business. You want to pussify this country? You want to vaginize football? Get the hell out, or they’1ll be doing your autopsy. And Bennet, shaken, holding now a silent phone, and we cu

dialogues.speaker: BLACK SCREEN
dialogues.text: Two rings, three. SNAP. Light comes on. We’re-- INT. BEDROOM - BENNET’S CONDO - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet’s alone. Alarm clock reads 4AM.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (picks up) Hello? Hello? Now a pattern of clicks and hisses. Then silence. Now-- Tap Tap. Bennet whirls, jumpy. Branch scraping the window Bennet stops. Feels - what? Who? Goes to the window to lo outside. Car parked where cars park. One street lamp is o One car starts up, lights come on. And as it simply drive away-- Something makes him turn. Fast. Prema. She’s right there. She's always been right there. She holds the blanket open for him. REVEALING her full se Let me protect you. He slips in beside her. She wraps him in her arms. INT. BENNET’S CONDO - 7AM New rhythm to their morning. They’re shaken. She fixes breakfast. He dresses. A humming fear. He’s tight. Prema keeps the shade drawn. A bunker in here. Bennet on his way out. She hands him his lunch. Then-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 72. Phone rings. Again. They both look at it as at a ticking bomb. Bennet picks up but says nothing. A voice we know--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Dr. Omalu? (yes--) I took you to be an early riser. I didn’t want to call you at work. (and we INTERCUT--) 108 INT. KITCHEN - BAILES’ HOME - SIMULTANEOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bailes in running shorts, shoes. Run-sweat. Pittsburgh an New York papers on the table in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: (into phone) My name is Julian Bailes. Do you know who I am? I was team doctor for the Pittsburgh Steelers.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I know who you are.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Mike Webster was a personal friend.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Was he.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: You're in trouble, Dr. Omalu. But you're not wrong. (then) I'd like to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: 111 EXT. BAILES’ HOME - DAY Traditional plantation home. Veranda and gables. Oak-line drive bisects a fairway-sized lawn. Yukon SUV and Porsche the end of it. As Bennet comes up the long drive toward the massive home takes it all in. So this is how they live. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 73. Bailes comes out on the porch, waiting for him. Coming fr distance, we sense in him a hostility held in reserve. As Bennet stops, reaches for the sleeve of medical slides

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Is this a good idea?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: You tell me. INT. HOME OFFICE - BAILES’ HOME - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet with Bailes sitting around a work table. Coffee an sandwiches. Bailes at his microscope. The sleeve of slide open. Then backs away. Then goes to his desk. Pulls out a folder of lab reports. Photos. Illustrations. Graphs.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: The NFL has known about the concussion issue for years-- CLOSE ON THE REPORTS.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What you’re looking at is the research that formed the basis for the League’s concussion guidelines. In this study, some academics put helmets on monkeys and shook them real hard. Threw dogs and pigs and human cadavers down elevator shafts. (picks up another one) Helmets on crash test dummies and bashed them together. Conclusion? (reading--) “No striking player experienced neck injury or concussion.” Concussions are as dangerous as a hang-nail. Bennet waits for more, then, disbelief--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: And that was it?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: No. Then the NFL did what every big organization does. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 74.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They put together a commission to study the studies. Dr. Elliot Pellman’s Mild Traumatic Brain Injury committee.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Mild - before they knew. Conclusion first. (then) It’s the opposite of science. (and Bailes looks at him, Exactly)

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Know who else is on that committee?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Dr. Maroon?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Joe, yeah, he’s on there. Plus other team doctors. An equipment manager. (and) And two trainers - guys who tape knees for a living. (then) I was more interested in studying actual human football players, who could talk about their pain. After a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Why did you really want to see me, Dr. Bailes?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea how many Pittsburgh Steelers - just Steelers - died in the last few years? I’m not talking about older guys. I’m talking about players I knew. And just the ones I know about. (then) Twelve. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t want to see any more of these guys vanishing in the backs of pick-up trucks. (and we JUMP TO--) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 75.
dialogues.text: EXT. BACKYARD - BAILES’ HOME - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overlooking a wide expanse of yard, lawn, pool, designer garden. Bailes taking it all in. Bennet studies Bailes. This is a man in pain. Bennet rela

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: I know them. I was them. You’re doing this wrong.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: As long as the NFL denies the truth, nothing changes.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: (that’s right--) If they say it’s not true, it’s not true. They have to say it out loud.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I need to look the Commissioner in the eyes. Get me a meeting. Face-to- face, man-to-man. I cannot lose. Pause. Bailes looks to Bennet. At his innocence. Then--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: He doesn’t want to talk to you. Football doesn’t want to talk to you. (because--) Like my daddy - a Louisiana judge - always said-- (holds up two fingers; and, in an exaggerated aristocratic southern drawl) ‘Son, God is number one’- (now just one finger) ‘And football is number two’. (then) You’re not even American. You're not even African-American. You’re--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: A doctor. Bailes smiles, a little embarrassed at himself. Then--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: The NFL has kept everyone in the dark. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 76.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have turned on the lights and given its biggest bogeyman a name. (leaning in) And if they don’t get this reined- in, everything they have, everything they are, is vulnerable. (then) What’s happening now, what you think they’re doing to you? Is hothing. You have no idea how bad this could get for you. A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I did my own research on the NFL's brain injury committee. You know what Dr. Elliot Pellman is? He’s a rheumatologist. He’s a specialist in arthritis and joint pain. Can you tell me what a rheumatologist knows about the brain and brain disease? (and) Corporate men like this, in this country, come from Harvard and Yale. But Pellman went to medical school in Guadalajara.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Mexico? I didn’t know that. That’s beautiful. And looks at him - “I like you” -

dialogues.speaker: BAILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s unlikely I could get you in front of them. But two cases aren’t going to be enough. You have to keep going.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Just so you understand. This doesn’t show up on a CT scan. There is no diagnosis before death. For me to keep going more have to die.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, I no longer see a scenario in which that isn’t already happening. (and we cut to--) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  114 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plane lands behind Bennet and Prema stand before the Dr House. Framing begun. Basement poured, waiting like an em pool. Bennet checks the fence. Good strong fence. Good fences m good neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: He’s one of them.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: He’s in pain.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Can we trust him?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I don’t think we have a choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big bright glass room. Working committee of five bunkered around a table covered in paperwork. Gathering up-- One breaks away: DAVE DUERSON. Handsome, muscular 48-year ex-defensive back, all-star warrior. Hurries past us in the hall. Jones coming the other way--

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (on the run) Did I hear right? We’re losing you? Tapping you for Mayor of Chicago?!

dialogues.speaker: DUERSON
dialogues.text: Still a long long road, my friend- (as Jones turns a corner-)

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: All-World killer athlete to civilian to King, all in one lifetime! Ladies and gentlemen, I give you Mayor Dave Duerson! Who has. Figured. It. Out! And as Jones disappears we follow Duerson into the elevat © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duerson spins out of the NFL building.

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dave! It’s me, man. Andre Waters. (jaw tightening, because-) His way blocked by former d-back (like him), ANDRE WATERS but looks 60. Rough road. Bloated. Sweaty.

dialogues.speaker: DUERSON
dialogues.text: How you doin man? (knows all too well)

dialogues.speaker: WATERS
dialogues.text: Let me walk with you. (Duerson grits this out) I’m not good. It was all in the paperwork. (so desperate can’t do the small talk) But why’s the committee doing this?

dialogues.speaker: DUERSON
dialogues.text: There are five other trustees. You talk to them?

dialogues.speaker: WATERS
dialogues.text: You’re the only one who played. Who knows. What it is to be us-- (can’t deny that either; tries to keep going) You and me were the same. Bangers. Hitmen.

dialogues.speaker: DUERSON
dialogues.text: File the appeal.

dialogues.speaker: WATERS DUERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You denied the appeal. You look alright-- (manic, sweaty, hands can’t stop moving) Something’s wrong with me, man.

dialogues.speaker: WATERS
dialogues.text: Can't sleep. Eyes get crossed, it’s freaky, my right eye’s pinned left and my left’s pinned right. Weirds me out sometimes. (Duerson’s aching for daylight) Dave, look at me, man. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved. + eH  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 79.

dialogues.speaker: WATERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (and gets in front of Duerson)

dialogues.speaker: DUERSON
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: WATERS
dialogues.text: I paid dues twelve years! Made millions for those assholes. It’s not even your money. I’m just asking back what I gave--

dialogues.speaker: DUERSON
dialogues.text: (exploding now right there on Park Ave) Fat? Stop eating like a pig. Gotta headache? See a doctor--

dialogues.speaker: WATERS
dialogues.text: Been to twenty doctors! Just need rent money--

dialogues.speaker: DUERSON
dialogues.text: Get your shit together! You were a warrior! Get your hands off me! (Waters is palming him)

dialogues.speaker: WATERS
dialogues.text: ‘Deny, deny, hope they die.’ That’s what we say about you. Your goddamn motto. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, I’m sorry. Remember? When we were kids, playin is what we lived, for, man! (talking to Duerson’s back because--) Duerson performing that move they teach d-backs Day 1 in camp, swim past the block at line of scrimmage to destroy QB. And Duerson swims past Waters down Park--

dialogues.speaker: WATERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t got another play left! Dave! (then) Somebody help me! --now leaving Waters to watch Duerson vanish until he’s alone, holding his head because the migraine has come, in sea of strangers who have no fucking clue who he ever was nor will they ever care. And we cut to-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --in Philadelphia Eagles jersey. Playing days: chiseled; direct gaze of a carnivore. PULL BACK TO REVEAL-- “Eagles Defensive Back Andre Waters, 44, commits suicide” The paper in Wecht’s hands. Wecht standing outside Bennet little office, as Bennet walks up in his scrubs--

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: (reading to Bennet) “--known as ‘Dirty Waters’, notorious for his aggressive style of play-- (and FLASH TO--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otherwise MUTE, under--

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Devastating hits that filled highlight reels ... died of a self- inflicted gunshot wound to the head.” Wecht looks up at Bennet. And as he hands him the paper a leaves him standing there--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poor Cracker South. Crabgrass pushing through sandy scrub. Eagles balloons rise from the coffin. A propped ph of Waters from playing days. CAMERA FINDS BENNET at the edge of the crowd. He's clocke a league REPRESENTATIVE in a suit. Now an ex-PLAYER or th First time Bennet’s been face-to-face with the live human involved. And it feels like a mistake. Flop-sweaty, he tu to go. While-- O.S. someone starts coming at him through the tombstones. MAN, AFRICAN-AMERICAN. Big strides. Extreme emotion on hi face. Fury? Fear? Bennet spots him, spots that, picks up pace. Big guy closing in. Running for the car now-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  120
Al21 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 81.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hey! Get over here--! (on top of Bennet now, breathing labored) Why’d you do that, man? Bennet terrified, braces to be hit. Or something. But the doubles over, trying to catch breath.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Christ-- (out of breath) You were leaving. But Andre's mother. You wanted to talk to Andre's mother, right? (INTERCUTTING with--) INT. BAILES’ HOME - EVENING Bailes at his desk, bathed in computer light, solitary contemplation. Mindlessly stirring his drink with his fin And we PULL AROUND Bailes’ head and over his shoulder on HE'S SEEING: a picture of Strzelczyk. Now--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neat. Devout. Family pictures. Legions of grandchildren. Bennet sitting adjacent to WATERS’ MOTHER, 70. They're watching a DVD of an Eagles game ON THE TV: Waters getting hit so hard he lays on the ground, unconscious. Then is helped up. Then wanders toward the opposing sideline. Then is led back straight to the huddl staggering through the next play. Waters’ mother watches Bennet watch. She’s seen it a hund times. She wants to watch Bennet’s reaction. Alternativel volcanic with grief, and letting rays of light burn throu WATERS’ MOTHER He said he was alright. He said he was dazed for a minute then he was alright-- (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bailes pulls up in his Porsche, parks. Crosses the street Gritty industrial Pittsburgh. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  121 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 82. A woman in the window feels him, turns: a changed Keana Strzelczyk. Thinner. Tired. As Bailes hesitates, then goe in, we go back to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet and Mrs. Waters. WATERS’ MOTHER Let me tell you about my son. We used to call him Spanky. His daddy gave him that name-- And reaches in her bag WATERS’ MOTHER (CONT’D) I’m going to read you something. The last thing he wrote me. (reading from a letter) “,..There isn’t a day that goes by that I don’t thank God for blessing me with you as my mom. Happy Mother’s Day. Your son, Andre M. Waters.” (then) His signing bonus, he bought me this house. He bought all his brothers cars. He was the sun and we were planets. Bennet’s eyes closed, nodding, feeling Andre’s presence. WATERS’ MOTHER (CONT’D) After he gave me this card, he said, “Ma, I’m ready to go.” He knew people started thinking he was crazy.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Not crazy. He’d already become someone else-- And she looks at him. Her eyes welling up. Anger. WATERS’ MOTHER BENNET (CONT'D) Suicide. He took it out of He was sick. God’s hands. WATERS’ MOTHER He definitely had this disease? Because I want to believe that. Because you’re not supposed to put your own child in the ground. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  122 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 83. WATERS’ MOTHER (CONT'D) Nature’s not supposed to work that way. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. You want what’s left of my son? Because Dr. Omalu, I don't want to feel another thing I have to survive. Don’t let me feel hope, then not have this come out right. (and takes his hand)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I understand, yes-- And Bennet slides next to her. Takes a knee. Bows, prays. prays. She’s crying. Now he’s crying. Then-- WATERS’ MOTHER BENNET (CONT'D) Heavenly Father, you know And please lead us to the every heart. Please mend our truth. Soothe this family souls. with your grace. WATERS’ MOTHER In Jesus’ name, Amen. Then she abruptly stands. Drying her eyes. WATERS’ MOTHER (CONT’D) I’m going to get us some coffee. (and exits, and back to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find Bailes & Keana at a table outside, under the awni It’s cool. Neither feel it. Their breath ballooning in fr of their faces--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: You look good. How are the kids?

dialogues.speaker: KEANA STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: The kids are fine. I am fine. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I couldn’t make the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: KEANA STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: No one made it to the funeral. Then. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: You heard about Mike Webster. And she just looks at him. She heard.

dialogues.speaker: KEANA STRZELCZYK
dialogues.text: And Terry Long. And and and. And who else? What do you really want to ask me, Julian? (and now a hard cut to--)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET WALKING IN DARKNESS
dialogues.text: Following him through a lightless basement passage. All w HEAR, his footsteps, the thrum of a boiler, hum of fans. Then - BANG! - he shoves at a door. Bailes is standing ou there in the night in the rain. Bennet lets Bailes enter,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet leads Bailes through the underground tunnel, throu warren of basement labs, to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where Wecht is waiting in the half-dark. Around them, t silhouettes of fresh bodies for tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (introducing) This is Dr. Wecht. Bailes shakes his hand. We’re TIGHT ON WECHT. He’s not so sure about Bailes - friend of enemy, fish or fowl? Bennet hands Bailes a short stack of slides. Hands Bailes a short stack of slides. BENNET (CONT’D) Andre Waters. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 85. Bailes goes to the microscope. Bows, peers in. Now Bennet hands him-- BENNET (CONT’D) Justin Strzelczyk. Long pause as Bailes looks and looks at the one slide. Bennet stirs. Glances worriedly into the dark. Where the bodies are waiting. As if he’s heard something. He mumble “I’m sorry,” moves closer to the others, gives the angry corpses room. (We see all this. And Wecht does. Bailes doesn’t. Because he doesn’t know to.)

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: (in his own world) I just kept sending him back out there.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: What were you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: You have to be part of all that. Down there on the sidelines with them. Whatever it takes to keep them in the game. To keep it all going. Tape, needles, Vicodin, Torodol, Lidocaine, Percocet. (and) Lexapro. Zoloft. (they’re looking at him, then--) Tires. Oil. You’re a mechanic keeping the race cars on the track. Pause there. Then, hearing himself, how that sounded. Bai looks at Bennet. But--

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: That’s not medicine. I don’t know what that is.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: It’s business. (they look at him) It’s just business. And there it is. And then what he’s been waiting for:

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Three cases is the scientific burden of evidence. We have four. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  128

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 86.
dialogues.text: BENNET (CONT’D) (and now) We are past what the NFL can and cannot deny. It’s bigger than they are. Now they have to listen to us. Bailes. Conflicted. Resigned. Defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atop Mt. Washington, perched high over the wishbone confluence of the Ohio, Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers. massive stadium where the Steelers play. And the Pittsbur skyline. We find Bennet and Bailes at a four-top by the picture window. Each has a drink. It’s llpm. Bennet looking throu the reflections of staff cleaning up. Bailes off into spa They've been sitting for a couple hours. Bailes looks to watch, Goddammit--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: He wanted to do this two hours ago. And now a reflection in the window turns Bennet. Joe Maro is crossing toward them. Hesitates at the table, takes a chair on Bailes’ side. A beat of them all together, silent. Maroon doesn’t apologize.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: I said five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: He doesn’t want a drink. (and Maroon goes right into it--)

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: Your conclusions are a total misinterpretation of facts. To say Webster and Long and Waters were killed by football is-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 87.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Fallacious reasoning. Yes, I know. And maybe you haven’t heard, Dr. Maroon. But the world is not flat. Maroon vibrates with rage.

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: (to Bailes) Where’s he going with this?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Just hear him out--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I want to propose a formal controlled study. Bring together the best minds in America. We should be working together.

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: Who do you think you're talking to?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: I was President of the Congress of Neurological Surgeons.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Yes. And I was the doctor who performed the autopsies of Mike Webster and Terry Long. Your men. Your men under your care. (he has Maroon’s attention) Do you know what Mike Webster's wife said? If she knew he was sick, if she knew what he’d become was this disease, she would have been nicer to him. But he died. Everything broken. Their lives ruined. (then) You took an oath. Tell the truth!

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: The truth? The truth is the National Football League is a salvation! It employs hundreds of thousands of people. We’ve sent thousands of kids to school. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 88.

dialogues.speaker: MAROON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We ship players to war zones to entertain the troops-- (nods down at Heinz Field, and crescendoing--) The ownership of this football club has given millions to charity. The NFL runs clinics on child obesity. You want me to go on?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: It’s not necessary--

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: It is necessary. Some of our players would be what without the NFL? Where would their kids be? Do you know where most of these guys would be?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Alive. Maroon looks at him, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: The NFL is the most popular sport in America because it is goddamn fantastic. You think they make people play? People want to play. (point outside, down there, at Heinz Field, glowing) Right there is the beating heart of this city. Not the symphony. Not the ballet. Every city the Steelers play in, it’s the same. What do you want us to do, end it? Fold the National Football League?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (he’s not even answering that question--) Solve the problem. Solve. The Problem.

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: Who are you? (to Bailes) He performs autopsies. He's a pathologist--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Yes, a mere pathologist. That is so. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 89. Long heavy silence. Then--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: And what if he’s right? What if it’s true? Maroon HOLDS Bailes in place with a glare. Then, back to Bennet-— Yes-- Pause,

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: Do you understand the impact of what you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET MAROON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (forceful; angry again) Do you understand the impact. Of what you are doing? (because obviously Bennet could not possibly)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I said I did--

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: Let me tell you. Because you clearly do not. (now) If just 10-percent of mothers in America-- (and stops, gathers himself) Did you ever play football?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: It taught me everything I know about loyalty, teamwork, endurance, sacrifice. (then, leaning in) If 10-percent of mothers in America decide football is too dangerous for their sons to play, that’s it. It is the end of football. Kids. Colleges. Eventually, it’s just a matter of time, the professional game. then-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 90.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Joe. He’s not in the outcome business.

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: He has no business--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: And do you know what history does to people - trained physicians - who ignore science-- ? Maroon tries to interject.

dialogues.speaker: SIR, I AM NOT DONE--
dialogues.text: Maroon shocked to silence. BENNET (CONT’D) History laughs! (then) Deny my work, the world will deny it. But men will continue to die. And families will go on being destroyed. Maroon looks hard to Bailes, then Bennet. And his proposa

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: Are you sure you want to do this?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I could ask you the same question. (a pause, then--)

dialogues.speaker: MAROON
dialogues.text: I’1ll get back to you. (and fast he’s out of his seat and heading out--) Leaving Bennet and Bailes alone. A long moment of silence

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Well, that went well. And the two of them are left staring down at Heinz Field rising massive like the Roman Coliseum out of the city’s beating heart. Now we START TO HEAR IN PRE-LAP-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  129 131 132 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 91.

dialogues.speaker: JONES, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: (reading) --After examining the remains of former National Football League player Andre Waters, a neuropathologist in Pittsburgh, Dr. Bennet Omalu, is claiming that Mr. Waters had sustained brain damage from playing football and he says that led to his depression and ultimate death-- (continuing over--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones stands before Tagliabue, reading the paper aloud.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: It gets worse. (then) Dr. Julian Bailes, medical director for the Center for the Study of Retired Athletes and the chairman of the department of neurosurgery at West Virginia University, said, “Unfortunately, I’m not shocked.” (looks up--) There’s more Omalu. More Bailes.

dialogues.speaker: TAGLIABUE
dialogues.text: Bailes. Why do I know that name?

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Steelers team doctor. Neurologist for the Players Association.

dialogues.speaker: TAGLIABUE
dialogues.text: Oh wow.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Yeah. Wow. (then) The Times is calling it a potential epidemic. Paul. It’s not the Sports section. Not Science. A-l. Front page. New York Times. Above the fold. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  133 134 135 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACK Tagliabue and Jones crossing from their suite to a of heavy oak doors. The doors open, and as they enter, we GLIMPSE over their shoulder a long luxurious table encirc by a dozen WHITE MEN waiting in grim silence. You can sme the privilege, the power. Ownership. And as the doors clo us out--

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: --his 17 years as Commissioner of the National Football League comprised the most lucrative and stabilizing reign perhaps in the history of pro sports-- (and we PULL BACK to reveal we’re--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wecht, Sullivan and the Techs, all watching the TV, and a hastily arranged “press conference”. Bennet enters.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Nice going, Bennet. You killed off the commish. Bennet confused, elated. As, to Jones’ left we now see Tagliabue. To his right is incoming Commissioner ROGER GOODELL, 47 and sandy-haired.

dialogues.speaker: TAGLIABUE/TV
dialogues.text: Roger has worked for the NFL since he was 21. He lives football, breathes football, but he’s younger, more handsome-- (laughter, then, serious--) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 93.

dialogues.speaker: TAGLIABUE/TV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And understands how to take ‘America’s Game’ into the future. There is a new sheriff in town-- Upon which Wecht walks in. As Goodell takes the lectern. Folksy, telegenic in that Clintonesque way. Sullivan & Wecht exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: GOODELL/TV
dialogues.text: The NFL isn’t just a sports league. It’s an entertainment product. What I’m here to do now, my main responsibility, is to protect the shield, America’s Game. (the NFL logo) --I want us to go on enjoying our great game knowing our kids love it, respect it, never stop having fun--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: They heard. They’re listening.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Sure. Morning in America. A new day in the NFL. (TIGHT on Goodell; sarcastic) He looks like your drinking buddy. While, on TV, Pellman appears, glum, beside Goodell. WECHT (CONT’D) And there’s your buddy, Pellman, again. The knee man from Guadalajara. (and leaves, as)

dialogues.speaker: BROADCAST/TV, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Roger Goodell’s been at the forefront of every major decision the NFL has made over the past dozen years. His biggest challenge now? Keeping the good times rolling for a $6-billion a year business.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: You're screwed now. (and walks out) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  136 137 138

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: Julian Bailes is on the phone-- And Bennet crosses to the phone, picks up--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Turn on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (into phone) I'm watching it right now.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: He’s shaking up Pellman’s brain injury committee. They’re asking for a concussion summit, a full presentation. In Chicago. Next week. On Bennet’s face--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: We have our chance, Bennet.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: EXT. WESTIN HOTEL - O’HARE AIRPORT - CHICAGO -

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT/ESTABLISHING
dialogues.text: One of the big ones out by the airport. Constant whine of wash. It’s snowing. Really starting to come down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Generic franchise room. Muzak, formica tabletops and mid- layover SALESMEN. We find Bennet and Bailes in a corner booth doing a presentation run-through. Laptop open on Power Point. Ben on his second drink. Bailes into maybe his third. Looking it all as if at blueprints for D-Day. Bennet jacked. Bail knows half his men are going to perish.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (reciting) “The facts speak for themselves. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 95.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These brains, strangled by protein unleashed by repetitive head trauma related to football, tell an irrefutable story--” (and looks up, Good?)

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Maybe throw in some football stuff. Not medical terms. Things we say--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Why do I need to say what they say? I thought that’s why we’re here.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: You have, what, seven degrees? Eight? You're one of the smartest people they’1l ever meet. You know what? You’ll be fine. Bennet takes Bailes in.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: How about you? What will you be? Bailes fumbling with an INSERT picture of MIKE WEBSTER, b half-squatting, eyes tethered to the eyes of the nose-gua in his face, furiously focused. And now a TIGHT on Bailes we PUSH IN, his face growing in frame--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: It can be a boring, violent, stupid game. And it can be Shakespeare. The game looks like life. I know you can’t see how beautiful that all is - I don’t blame you. (then, reverie done) But this isn’t fun for me. Everyone we're going to see tomorrow I know personally. That feeling you get when someone you love and respect screws you over? They will have it. And there’s not a damn thing I can do about it. We’re in on his eyes now. Maybe what he’s seeing. And out his reverie--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: You already did that yourself. (Bailes looks up, What?) When you picked up the phone. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 95a.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you called me. (now-- ) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  139 140 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 96.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Christ. They’re here. Bennet confused, follows Bailes’ gaze to the bar. Where a cluster of NFL officials have arrived. Pellman, Maroon, Jones, couple others. Pellman the schlubby one. Goodell crosses and joins them for a word with Jones. Jon whispers in Goodell’s ear. Maroon pivots, turns his back, waving for the bartender. Says something to Pellman. Pell laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (under his breath) He’s such an ass. But opaque, tight, Bailes shuts the laptop. On his face, violent collision of choice and consequences.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: We better get some sleep. INT. HOTEL ROOM - WESTIN O’HARE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet’s sitting on the bed against the wall in his cloth We're TIGHT on his face. A kind of nervous excitement and dread. He will not sleep tonight. And we HEAR a firm RAP on the door, and Bennet’s head tur and we cut to--

dialogues.speaker: HIS HOTEL ROOM DOOR
dialogues.text: It opens. Bailes is standing in the hall in a suit. And w SWING AROUND and find Bennet in the same. Cinching his ti It’s the next morning. Bennet’s suit is immaculate. Pocke square. There’s an ironing board out. He’s freshly ironed everything. He’s nervous as shit.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: We need to talk. Bailes steps in. His expression like he just bit down on something rancid.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: There’s no easy way to say this so I’m just going to say it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 97.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They aren’t going to let you speak. They don’t even want you in the room. I told you. They will not accept you as the face of this issue. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want me to do it. Pause. Bennet shocked. Rocked.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: One of their own.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET BAILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They want to pretend-- You don’t exist.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: You said Goodell is good--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: They still have to sit there and listen.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: To you.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Yes, me. You blew up their world.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET BAILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And yours. Yes. Mine.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: And how can an African know this subject better than them? Bennet looks at him a long moment. Fish or fowl? Us/them?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or better than you? Bailes stunned. Confused. Now livid, explodes--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: (that power/hostility held in reserve surfacing--) Wait a second ... You think this is about Bennet Omalu? I’m not here for you. I’m here because people are dying-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  141

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: You're here for redemption! You're here to use me to cleanse your sins!

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: You self-righteous bastard! Do you have any idea what I could have, how much I could have, if I went back to my side of the ball? Just kept quiet? Everything in my world is telling me not to agree with you. Except one thing - science. So I’m here. Not down there in that audience. Up here, beside you. What do_you want from me? How much more can I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And HOLD on them a long beat. And Bailes is right. And Be knows it, is ashamed. And is going to take it in the ass because it’s the only thing to do--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: You're right, I’m sorry. Go. Take it. All of it. And you convince them, Julian--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: I'm sorry-

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Convince them, Julian-- (and as Bailes turns and marches down the hall) Convince them! (now cut to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The huge, weird hub of three different enormous conferenc rooms. Empty. A MAINTENANCE PERSON is pushing a vacuum. Bennet stands against one of those removable accordion wa Trying not to look at his reflection in the wall of mirro Trying not to stare at the double doors to the conference room. Where it’s all happening. Pacing now. As a BEEFY PLAINCLOTHES SECURITY GUARD (NFL? Hotel?) cros the expanse, approaching--— © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 99.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY
dialogues.text: Sir, this is a private function. You're not supposed to be in this area.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: You're right, I’m supposed to be in there-- (in THERE, past the big dude )

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY
dialogues.text: I’m going to have to ask you step away and return to the lobby with the other guests. (and he’s in Bennet’s face now)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Don’t put your hands on me! Get your hands off me! Now the double doors push open at us. Football officialdo on its feet in there and starts to pours out. Bennet’s PO locks on the one black man. Duerson, vibrating with rage. Right up in Bennet’s face--

dialogues.speaker: DUERSON
dialogues.text: My father can’t remember a goddamn thing. And he never played a day of football. He was too busy working. In a factory. You quack. You think I’m some boy you can control? Take your bullshit science, go back to Africa, and get away from our game-- (and moves on, and--) Bennet, stunned, can see Pellman back in the conference r with Goodell and Jones-- And Jones looks up, and they HOLD a look. And we're in SL MO, and Jones slowly blinks, turns away, and-- The doors swing close, leaving Bennet looking at Bailes. Bailes is sweaty. Stunned. Like he’d been punched in the face.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Roger Goodell just said Justin Strzelczyk may have gotten his concussions swimming. In a swimming pool. (then) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  142 143 144 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 100.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was a set-up. They needed to say they heard us. So they can goddamn bury us. Bennet HEARS nothing but a low-grade hum. Bailes slips ou frame as Bennet floats past Bailes into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And stops. Because Goodell, Pellman, Maroon and Jones are setting up for a summing-up. News conference. National cameras. Background with NFL logo hung dropped behind the lectern. As Goodell takes his place, adjusts his mic--

dialogues.speaker: GOODELL
dialogues.text: This is an important day in the National Football League. We’ve had some very good dialogue, which will help us improve the care for our players.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: What do you think when you hear about former NFL players who are suffering from symptoms that have only been seen in boxers or people over 80-years old? What does that say about the effect of concussions on players?

dialogues.speaker: GOODELL
dialogues.text: I’m not a doctor here. But you have to look at their entire medical history. From my standpoint, not being a doctor, that just makes logical sense. You’re seeing some great scientists and doctors, who have done terrific work in this area, sharing information. They don’t all agree. The NFL has had a committee of expert doctors and scientists going on this for 14 years. This is an evolving science and that’s okay. We're pushing in on Bennet, listening to all this, watchi it all evaporate. Pellman jumping in-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  145 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 101.

dialogues.speaker: PELLMAN
dialogues.text: While I agree with the Commissioner, as I was discussing with other NFL medical personal, no empirically determined proof was presented today. Because there simply isn’t any. The truth is - and we will be delivering this directive to our players - that current research with professional athletes has not shown that having More than one or two concussions leads to permanent problems, if each injury is managed properly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet starts to back away, as--

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2 GOODELL
dialogues.text: Are you comfortable with the I don’t know about level of care for former comfortable. I’m not sure I players? understand what you mean. Bennet turning now, exiting as the news conference drones

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do you think the league is currently doing enough for players, or do you think you can do more--? And as the pile-on grows and crescendoes, and now FADES, FADING IN, in PRE-LAP--

dialogues.speaker: NFL FILMS NARRATOR, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: (operatic baritone) From whistle to gun, there are enough major collisions in pro football to stock a junkyard for a century-- Bennet has left the room, gone, the doors flapping behind

dialogues.speaker: NFL FILMS PROMO REEL, (4-WALLED)
dialogues.text: Two BALTIMORE RAVENS ready for a play by BUTTING HELMETS repeatedly. This SLO-MO, under a swelling elegaic score, if two mythic rams. Now--

dialogues.speaker: NFL FILMS NARRATOR, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Hitting is what separates player from player. One team from another. Pretender from contender. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved. eK  146 147 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 102.

dialogues.speaker: NFL FILMS NARRATOR, (OVER)
dialogues.text: And chumps from champions-- (cuts to--) A montage, MUTE - cuts of BIG HITS. Only the sound of helmets/pads crashing, men grunting, gnashing--

dialogues.speaker: NFL FILMS NARRATOR, (OVER)
dialogues.text: And it is this, of course, that has always been part of football’s appeal. Cinematic, like a war movie- Now churning arms and legs. Punctuated by frames of recei and others taking devastating hits. The hit frames synche the rhythm of the music.

dialogues.speaker: NFL FILMS NARRATOR, (OVER)
dialogues.text: A league where the meek do NOT inherit the turf. A game of thunder! and destruction! (now cut to--)

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE GOLDBERG/NARRATING, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: According to the NFL’s own numbers, half of all players with concussions, were being sent back into the same game. Including some who were actually knocked out cold. We asked the head of the NFL's committee on concussions at the time, if that was a good idea. (now to--)

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: TV _4-WALLED - HBO’S ‘REAL SPORTS’ WITH BRYANT GUMBEL (AC

dialogues.speaker: FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: And CORRESPONDENT BERNIE GOLDBERG.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE GOLDBERG
dialogues.text: That could lead to medical problems, no?

dialogues.speaker: IRA CASSON
dialogues.text: Returning to play when you shouldn’t return to play? There’s no clear evidence that has led to medical problems, if that’s what you're asking me. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 103. And a cut over to his interview: 60ish, tweedy dresser, shaggy ring of white hair. “Dr. Ira Casson, newly-appoint NFL Medical Director”.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE GOLDBERG/NARRATING
dialogues.text: Back in 2007, Ira Casson, was head of a team of NFL doctors who had looked into the issue, and determined that the concern over head injuries, was over blown.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muttering in Swahili) Wao wana kichaa! Kuma nina. Fala! (and REVERSE to find)

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE GOLDBERG
dialogues.text: (addressing Casson) Is there any evidence, as far as you're concerned, that links multiple head injuries among pro football players with depression?

dialogues.speaker: CASSON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE GOLDBERG
dialogues.text: With dementia?

dialogues.speaker: CASSON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE GOLDBERG
dialogues.text: With early onset of Alzheimer's?

dialogues.speaker: CASSON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE GOLDBERG
dialogues.text: (disbelief creeping in) Is there any evidence as of today that links multiple head injuries with any long-term problem like that?

dialogues.speaker: CASSON
dialogues.text: In NFL players?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE GOLDBERG
dialogues.text: Yeah. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  149

dialogues.speaker: CASSON
dialogues.text: No. (and HOLDING Goldberg’s near-smirk, we go to--) Bennet. Head in hands. And just when we think this cannot worse, we start HEARING in PRE-LAP:

dialogues.speaker: GOODELL/TV, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: The first pick of the Houston Texans--! (and cut hard to--)

dialogues.speaker: GOODELL
dialogues.text: Amobi Okoye! Defensive lineman from the University of Louisville-- As Goodell shakes hands with Bennet’s cousin, Amobi, swee smiled mountain of a man. We watch a TIGHT of Amobi, huge grin, holding up his new jersey, “OKOYE - 91” - as he’s b drafted. Then PULL BACK TO REVEAL we’re-- INT. BENNET’S CONDO Bennet watching the circus-like spectacle on his TV. Now in hands. Now shuts it off. It’s late. Quiet. Bennet stops at the kitchen table. Drea House material - floor plans, paint color charts, brochur for brick face - spread before him. Weary, as he taps it all into a neat pile, and in a singl TRACKING SHOT we follow him to the window. Where we take the back of St. Benedict illuminated high atop the church above us all. Now into the bedroom, where he stands watch Prema sleep. Then gets to his knees, his face by Prema’s belly--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Hi. This is your father. (what to say? so insecure) I am in deep shit. I haven’t done anything wrong, but I am being punished. Your mother and I are being tested. It might be not so good out here when you arrive. You are still with God. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your face is still the face of God. Please tell God to help me. (and closes his eyes, and-) We slide to Prema’s face. Eyes open. Awake. Listening. Th INT./EXT. PREMA’S CAR (MOVING) /MOON TOWNSHIP - DAY Prema driving herself there for first time alone. More pregnant. Humming to a pop song on the radio. Clarion voi Her eyes tick up to the rear-view. A sedan. Nondescript. Windshield opaque with sky. Keeping pace. And it’s still keeping pace. She stops singing. She turns turns. She turns again. It keeps going. She keeps going. It reappears. Now she’s there. In the neighborhood. Grass. Shrubbery is She looks over at their home. Then the rear-view. Car’s g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sullivan leading Bennet upstairs. Before the top he stops them in the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Why does Cyril want to see me?

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Hopefully to fire you. (and they head into--) INT. WECHT’S OFFICE - ALLEGHENY COUNTY CORONER - DAY Where Wecht is waiting with two FBI AGENTS.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: What is this? © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 106. Bennet now looking from Wecht to the Agents. Goes still, an animal will at the scent of danger. Then--

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: I am being relieved of my duties.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT WECHT
dialogues.text: Dr. Wecht is being indicted Eighty-four Federal counts. on eighty-four Federal Mail fraud, wire fraud, and counts, including-- related offenses arising from his use of government resources to benefit his private practice. Sending personal faxes, mileage vouchers, misusing office stationary--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET WECHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Faxes? Faxes.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: They couldn’t come up with something that stupid in Nigeria.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Using public property for private gain.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: You do know the man has been a public servant for decades--

dialogues.speaker: AGENT 2
dialogues.text: Have you ever performed any private services on county time? A pause as Bennet does the math. Then realizes--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Do you mean the death row case? I was on my time! I saved an innocent man’s life.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Apparently we’ve both hurt the government's feelings. (then) This has nothing to do with him. (meaning Bennet) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: We don’t want you, Dr. Omalu. But we can have you.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: What does that mean? Everything all at once. Bennet’s walls crashing around hi

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: They are going to want your testimony. (and some sort of gesture tells him--)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Against you? (the silence says yes; turning to the agent) Is this because his name was on my research?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT 1
dialogues.text: (dead-pan) What research is that, Dr. Omalu? Bennet HOLDS his look. A stare-down. A long beat, then--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (this is bullshit--) I‘ll resign first.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT 2
dialogues.text: In which case your immigration status will be revised. Since your status requires full-time employment.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (so absurd he actually laughs) I‘1l get another job in some other city. (and very - too - quickly)

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: That would be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVER BENNET’S SHOULDER as he walks slowly through the aut chamber. Past Sullivan. Gracie. His hands shake. Knees so © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 107A. Sound and light as if from the bottom of a pool. Muffled. Slow. Prismed. Up the stairs into his-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 108. INT. BENNET’S OFFICE - COUNTY CORONER - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet enters. Wecht trails in after him.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
