dialogues.text: I said make us both come out okay, not professional ruination. And takes in, maybe for the first time, Bennet’s little shitbox of an office. The shitty high-school microscope. WECHT (CONT’D) This is a terrible goddamn chair. (looks around; the computer ) You had to buy that, too?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Everything.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: I didn’t do good enough by you.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: They won’t make me say one word against you.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: What’s there to say? Cyril Wecht’s a loud-mouth asshole? Yeah, well. I don’t care. I’m tired. My balls are low-- Then. Why he’s really here-- WECHT (CONT’D) Look. Whoever - whatever - takes my place - everything is up for grabs now. (Bennet isn’t reading him) The CTE material - Webster, Long, Strzelczyk, Waters--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: And maybe the Allegheny County Medical Examiner suddenly develops a storage problem. And certain brain matter is suddenly taking up too much space. I won’t be able to protect it. Or you. (then) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 108A.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I asked Sullivan where it all was. He had no idea. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 109.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Because it’s in my coat closet. Wecht stares at him a beat.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: You’re a goddamn renegade, you know that? (then) What if they get a warrant?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: On suspicion of what, science? Wecht laughs. Then, the bottom line--

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: We got screwed. You don’t deserve it. Know what the worst part is? How easy it was.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (look at me--) I can’t go back to Nigeria. All I am is here. My child is going to be born American.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: (don’t worry so much--) I‘1l get you a job. You can work in the prison laundry with me. (starts to leave, then, fuck it) Call the surgeon. We need a goddamn drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're following Bennet wobbling slightly through the narr passage from men’s room to the bar. It’s lunch-time. Bailes and Wecht lean waiting for him. O guys are drunk. Bennet stares at the fish--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: I’m telling you there’s only one thing they’re thinking about now: how many more years of clean profit they can squeeze out of professional football. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 110.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT BENNET
dialogues.text: Before they have to put a (and mimics) warning label on the sport. “The Surgeon General Has Determined that Playing Football is Dangerous to Your Health.” (his glass) Johnny Walker--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Before people stop buying team jerseys. The NFL’s already gaming this out, the merchandise, the cable deals, endorsement deals, advertising, when all that will start to skid sideways, then slide. (then) Did you know Tagliabue was law partner at Covington & Burling, the firm that represented the seven Big Tobacco companies?

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Of course he was.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: The law firm that now represents the National Football League.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Of course it does.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: In my last year with the Steelers, the League moved a game froma Sunday to a Tuesday because of a blizzard. The League said it wasn’t worried about TV ratings because the NFL is immune even from acts of God. Wecht is starting to give Bailes a dark look.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (drinking) And now here comes this Omalu, mere pathologist and foreigner of questionable background.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Now highly deportable pathologist and foreigner. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 111.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: And then there is the National Football League--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Immune from acts of god -

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: --And its 25 years of expert brain research. Bennet Omalu vs. football. Bennet Omalu vs. America. That’s their playbook. Pause. They’re actually quite drunk. Wecht up-ends his bourbon. After a beat-- Pause.

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Know how many people cigarettes killed since the warning label went on? 200-million. 5-million a year. But there are more smokers now than ever. People want what they want.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (dawning even on him) Maybe this all makes football bigger. Maybe all this somehow means more, more money, more of everything. Pause. Sobering--

dialogues.speaker: WECHT
dialogues.text: Because it’s the goddamn Roman Coliseum, right? And the people can’t get enough of the car crash of it all. They drink. Contemplating that. Wecht is staring at Bailes, as if at a traitor. Bailes ca hold his look, turns away, as Bennet, under his breath--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Until someone dies people give a damn about. (then cut to--) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  152 153 154 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet at the cross-walk waiting for the light to change, returning from the bar. A Police cruiser - sirens piercing - smashes by. Bennet t to stare at it. Suddenly nervous. And instinctively turns pick-up truck has stopped alongside. The DRIVER - no one special - looks at him. Eyes meet. Bennet looks away. As signal changes. And the car moves off-- Gracie’s broken away from the building, running to him, waving, as in a bad fucking dream--

dialogues.speaker: GRACIE
dialogues.text: Bennet! ! (now smash to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet in a scrum of EMTs and NURSES running Prema in. DOCTORS converging. Prema pale, weeping, as, on the run--

dialogues.speaker: PARAMEDIC
dialogues.text: 30-year old female, G-1, P-zero, 18 weeks EGA pregnancy, heavy bleeding, suspected miscarriage--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet’s hands on Prema’s face. DOCTOR searching with the ultrasound wand. As all eyes on the image. The space wher the heart is - dark. A NURSE places a hand on Prema’s arm doctor says, Sorry. We SEE his mouth moving, but we’re in Bennet’s POV and he’s hearing nothing. He moves to Prema’ face, and holds it. Both of them crying.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (to the room) Will you please excuse us? (and when they are alone) I’m sorry I’m sorry. I made a mistake. This is my fault I’m sorry-

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: This isn’t your fault-- (and then we--) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  155 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet enters amidst the bouquets. “Your friends at the Coroner’s office”. He bends over Prema. Presses his foreh to hers. Sits. Takes in where they are. (All the places t are.)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I wish I never met Mike Webster.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Your work was beautiful. You are beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: But they destroyed us. I don’t understand why this is happening this way. What else do I have to do?

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Bennet. Look at me-- (and he does) Do you know what I chose to fake? (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. By now he is crying.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: We will have this family.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Yes, we will. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just not here. (It’s time to let go. And let God.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet walking through his nearly-finished home. Airy, li Built-ins. Faux-grand but grand nonetheless. Walks through his kids’ rooms. (There are two.) One alrea painted into a nursery. His master bath. Dragging his finger along his marble. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  164 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 114. Stops at the window. Transfixed by the McMansion across t street. Fresh shrubbery unwrapped, sod fresh. American Fa in. KIDS, 7 & 11, bikes, DAD assembles a bbq, MOM’s unpac the garage. Now down the stairs into his lab. The space carved for hi dissection table. His freezers. His.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello? Mr. Omalu?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (he’s so weary--) Dr. Omalu (and climbs to meet--) The CONTRACTOR. Standing in his new living room.

dialogues.speaker: CONTRACTOR
dialogues.text: I just need the measurements for the flat screens.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: That isn’t going to be necessary. (and now--)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET STANDING IN HIS FOYER
dialogues.text: And closes the new raw-wood door. Grabs a 2x4. Turns look at his walls. We don’t know what he will do. And - volcan he swings and-- BURIES it in sheetrock. BAM! Again. And Again. BAM! Dust. Splinters. And as he swings-- We PULL outside the house, TRACKING IN REVERSE, house RECEDING IN FRAME, the perfect windows, the perfect yard, baby foliage. GLIMPSES of Bennet in the window, swinging the guts of the house. Then stopping. Slipping to his kne weeping seething with rage-- As we keep going back. Rising, PULLING high and far from cul-de-sac, the subdivision. Everything in front of us - lots, the streets - so well designed. Such a good story. this. And as we keep we--

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: And OVER BLACK SCREEN, we HEAR Bennet singing: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: If ever you're in my arms again This time I'll love you much better If ever you're in my arms again This time I'll hold you forever--

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: INT./EXT. BENNET’S CAR/CENTRAL VALLEY - CALIFORNIA - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet - in a 2010 Mercedes sedan - crossing an ocean of Kansas-flat farmland. Dry and desolate. Tract after tract arid farmland, ranch homes sticking up out of the landsca like tombstones. Mexican DAY-LABORERS and tractors. And pulls up to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dropped amid the fields. Treeless. Single-story brick ranches. Sun-bleached. The sun is high. The air is 105. Bennet gets out with groceries and into-- INT. BENNET’S NEW HOME - LODI, CALIFORNIA - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet playing with a TODDLER in the gravelly back yard. up pool. Kneeling in the dirt, putting in tomato trellise TIME HAS PASSED. And Bennet looks up. He’s happy. Prema - pregnant with #2 waves behind glass-- Then cut to--

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  170

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humble pre-fab trailer. Blue-light fly zapper spilling de bugs. The refrigerated room is bumper-cars with dead migr laborers wrapped loosely in sheets. One poorly-trained ASSISTANT. A single slab. Bennet rolls out his special instruments. Every death always is sacred: “Tell me how this happened, Jose.” No one to tell him otherwise. And begins his work. A fleck on his sleeve, and off comes smock, and as he reaches for a fresh one--

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: INT. BEDROOM - BENNET’S NEW HOUSE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet asleep next to Prema. His arm draped over her preg belly protectively. Their kid’s bed against the wall. Tod calmly asleep.

dialogues.speaker: DUERSON, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: (manic, into phone) My mind’s slipping, man. I can’t find the goddamn words-- The SOUNDS of footsteps shuffling on carpet. Heavy breath Pants. Grunts. And now UP TO--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find Dave Duerson pacing. On his cell. Into a mirror. is that? Where are you? © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  177 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 117.

dialogues.speaker: DUERSON
dialogues.text: (manic, into phone) Something seriously wrong with my head-- We SEE laid out on his kitchen table, an issue of Sports Illustrated. The cover piece says “CONCUSSIONS” (the word superimposed over Steelers linebacker JAMES HARRISON mercilessly spearing a receiver). And photos of an ex-wife. Children. Parents. A portrait of himself in a Chicago Bears uniform.

dialogues.speaker: DUERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Gotta do it. Give it to them. I’m sorry. I gotta I just can’t do this-- And drops the phone. Now we see the gun in his other hand. .38 Special. Duerson heads to his bed. Lays on top of it. Slips a clea white sheet over himself to the neck. We’re right over hi As he puts the gun muzzle to his chest. Eyes wide. Right us: Goodbye. And--

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO BLACK
dialogues.text: Pause, then--

dialogues.speaker: OVER BLACK SCREEN
dialogues.text: WE HEAR A PHONE RINGING. Two rings, three. SNAP. Light comes on. Revealing-- INT. BENNET’S NEW HOME - LODI, CALIFORNIA -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clock reads midnight.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: (picking up) Hello? © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 118.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: It’s Julian. (and we INTERCUT Bailes in his robe in his kitchen-) Dave Duerson killed himself today. Bennet slips out of bed away from a sleeping Prema. Takes phone into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: He shot himself in the chest, Bennet. In the heart.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Oh my god--

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: He left a note. He said he was thinking about all NFL players. He wanted his brain donated. To be examined. He said we were right.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: He said that? Bennet has gone to stand at a window looking out on his humble little street.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Bennet? You there?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: For the brain’s last act to not just die, but preserve itself in the act of killing, to give an instruction to shoot into the chest - Julian, human beings don’t do that. PUSH IN on Bennet. His grief and anger.

dialogues.speaker: BAILES
dialogues.text: Bennet. Dave Duerson killing himself - the way he killed himself - they can’t explain this one. It’s undeniable now. It’s all going to unravel. And on Bennet blinking, trying to comprehend what Bailes saying to him, we SMASH TO-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  178 179 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 119. INT. BENNET’S NEW HOME - LODI, CALIFORNIA - DAY/EARLIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet in their modest bedroom. Before his cramped open closet. Flustered and overthinking the suits. 0.S. the ki plays and laughs. Prema enters. She’s pregnant. Bennet pulls out a conservative gray suit.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: That is what they wear. (and takes it from him and puts it back)

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: What do I say to them?

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Who do you speak for? When you know who you speak for you know what to say and what to mean. (pulls out a bold pin- striped suit) Go and give them what belongs to them. Tell them what’s really happening. Wear what you are. (and we SMASH TO--) BENNET’S FACE. HUGE IN FRAME. GAME FACE. SET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet in back. The DRIVER glancing at him in the rear-vi The phone STILL RINGING as we ADD and INTERCUT-- OUTSIDE THE LIMO, wide tree-lined streets. Expensive lawn Golf courses. Who can Bennet be that he’s going where he’ going?--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And its turreted Versailles-like grounds. The only other whites move mowers and bags. If a plantation were a castl Sign board at entrance: “Welcome National Football League Players Association Special Concussion Summit.” © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 184 CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 120.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a terrace letting out on the Atlantic. A Louis XVI b Murals. A fountain. Bennet left alone to dust off. Standi in the center of the obscene room-- Chooses to iron his suit in his underwear. And shave. Scraping his face, a tension surfaces. Eyes to hands. PUS CLOSE on his hands. Blade bowing against his cheek. Until slicing himself. He watches in the mirror the blood zag down his face. The drop, and as it falls, as it splatters the sink, cut away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet outside waiting against another mirrored wall. Thi one leafed in gold. Turns to the glass to cinch his tie. TIGHT ON HIS COLLAR: smudge of blood. He touches it. Deci to leave it there. And turns to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet approaches the podium. And turns to 500 faces. Mos players, former players, their families. But there is Jon and Pellman. NFL lawyers. Team doctors, player reps. And the wives. We know who they are. Because they’re in t 40's and 50’s. And because they are alone, no men beside them. Among them, Keana Strzelczyk. And her kids. We find Bailes. He nods at Bennet, smallest nod of accomplishment. Behind all that, toward the back: Mike Webster. Waiting, listening with intent. Bennet takes out his speech. Glances at the pages. Then u the audience. At Webster. In the suffocating silence. He grips and leans into the podium. STARES out there, weighing the costs of what he’d like to say against what might say. Capable now of anything--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I don’t hate football. My wife has started watching it. I see the grace, the drama. (a long pause) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 121.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I once said I wished I never met Mike Webster. I was wrong. He was committed, a captain, a warrior, quiet in his pain. He’s given us a gift. The gift of knowing. In the place I come from, we take care of our warriors. And give respect to those with the power to heal them. (his eyes stop on Mike Webster ) These men-- And stops. Looks away. Elsewhere. Finds Keana Strz, her k His eyes go back to Webster. And stay there.

dialogues.speaker: BENNET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --are not machines. Not commodity. Not video game figure. We loved them when they were heroes. By dying they speak for the living. And I speak for them. That is all I do. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive them. Forgive yourselves. Be at peace-- (and to Webster--) I thank you. And now Bennet simply stops and walks off. Every face in room turned his way. Here and there people have stood up. Players. Wives. As he exits. Not Webster. As Bennet turns for the exit, he spots him sitting where he sat. We’re SLO-MO. Pulling away but hang onto Webster. His hands on knees. Head down. Alone. As Keana Strzelczyk, behind him, is weeping in silence. H children, teenagers, cocooning her in their arms. They’re letting it go. Letting it all go. Bennet leaves all of th And now--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back, with the Breakers receding IN FRAME behind h As we HEAR, in PRE-LAP-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR JOHN CONYERS, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: But what’s the answer? Is there a link between playing professional football and the likelihood of contracting a brain-related injury, dementia, CTE? (and we cut to--)

dialogues.speaker: TABLE MIC
dialogues.text: We're in the Rayburn Building, U.S. Capitol. Behind Goode a packed gallery. Before him, an angry Congressional pane And Conyers is visibly frustrated--

dialogues.speaker: GOODELL
dialogues.text: (bumbling) We're doing everything we possibly can for our players now.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR JOHN CONYERS
dialogues.text: But what’s the answer?

dialogues.speaker: GOODELL
dialogues.text: The medical experts would know better than I with respect to that. But we are reinforcing our commitment— (now ADDING--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting like a pupil before the screen. Prema standing be him like a sentry. The phone starts to RING. HOLD, then--

dialogues.speaker: REP. LINDA SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: (livid) It reminds me of the tobacco companies sitting in this same chamber saying, ‘There is no link between smoking and damage to your health.’ A fucking Congressional warhead. Goodell flop-sweaty. And we INTERCUT--— BAILES, watching this at his office. WECHT, at the Chinatown Inn. SULLIVAN and GRACIE, in the break room. © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 123.
dialogues.text: JONES, from his office. AMOBI, on his iPhone in a football locker room. The phone RINGING over all this, as--

dialogues.speaker: REP. MAXINE WATERS
dialogues.text: We have heard from the NFL time and time again. You are always studying. You are always trying. You are always hopeful-- And as we PUSH IN on Goodell, wearing a look of constipat Then-- BACK TO Bennet’s home. His kid.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: This is all because of you. You did this. And as he turns now and looks out the window, at the sun- bleached street, the empty blue sky. As he looks around t at their humble digs. No dream house, this--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch crowd gone. Bennet sitting opposite DEPUTY MAYOR AL HIRSCHORN, 50. Washingtonian conservative. A WAITER sets a tray of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY MAYOR
dialogues.text: First time in Washington?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Never had the time.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY MAYOR
dialogues.text: Well, we're thrilled you accepted our invitation--

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: Washington D.C. is the capital of this nation. Lodi, California is the capital of lettuce. I was curious. (he smiles, and he does, he’s infectious--) © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY MAYOR
dialogues.text: (he pours herself coffee) Chief Medical Examiner of Washington, D.C. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY MAYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: means you’d also consult with the CIA and FBI, and any foreign government requesting the assistance of the United States government. (then) Essentially, you’re America’s forensic pathologist. You wouldn't have to put on scrubs, or perform an autopsy. You’re beyond all that now-- (as if that’s good news) Bennet is looking out the window. To the Department of Justice. The White House. Sidewalks hurrying with people suits who strap into the cockpits that fly the nation. DEPUTY MAYOR (CONT’D) Would you like to know about the benefits package?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I’m sure it’s fine. The Deputy Mayor ponders him. Feels his dilemma.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY MAYOR
dialogues.text: We know what you did, Dr. Omalu. You exemplify what it is to be an American. You belong in the nation’s capital. And it starts to well in him, the whole road here-- DEPUTY MAYOR (CONT’D) We'd like to offer you the job. He is barely containing his emotions. She sees it in him, looks away, giving him privacy, understanding--

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY MAYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don’t you take a couple days and think about it--? INT. BENNET’S NEW HOME - LODI, CALIFORNIA - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet’s overnight bag by the front door. Bennet and Prema in the kitchen. She’s washing. He’s dryi Their daughter at work at her doll house. Prema stops. Lo at him. Bennet deep in thought. Until, finally-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 125.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: Are you going to tell me what you said?

dialogues.speaker: BENNET
dialogues.text: I didn’t say anything. They gave me a week to decide. He wipes his hands. Takes in this humble house. His kids, toys. His pregnant wife.

dialogues.speaker: PREMA
dialogues.text: It’s everything you wanted. She’s not even sure about that. And neither is he now. An turns. They HOLD a long look. Then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet at his work. Pauses by a body on the slab. Left ha alights on the forehead. Right on the cold gray hand. Deep in thought. Then-- Bennet’s attention turns. Pulled from the humble autopsy chamber, we FOLLOW HIM into the hall. And REFOCUS on a TV playing on the CLERK’s desk. FADING IN--

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER/TV, (OVER)
dialogues.text: --sports fans and, frankly, all Americans across the nation are stunned today by the suicide of 42- year old football Hall of Famer Junior Seau, one of football’s most beloved, revered, and feared, players, who this morning committed suicide. Seau shot himself in the heart-- (now we SEE) FOOTAGE of bedlam. Handsome, Samoan face. Neck ropey with muscle. Toothy smile. To a crime scene. Yellow tape wrapp a beautiful seaside bungalow. Police. Ambulance. Now-- © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet. As his expression moves from shocked. To upset. To calm. Confirmed. Now we follow him into-- INT. BENNET’S OFFICE - LODI MORGUE - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennet passes his medical degrees on the wall. All of the there now. Framed and pretty. Plenty of room. And changes into his shirt, and crosses through frame in extreme f.g., and recrosses, dressing, working, busy -- a BEGIN A SLOW PUSH past him to the wall, where we find-- Brain cases stacked floor to ceiling. And files, maybe a hundred: Tom McHale, 45, Tampa Bay Buccaneers...Nathan Stiles, 17, Spring Hill High School.. Christopher Henry, 26, Cincinnati Bengals...Damien Nash, Denver Broncos...Curtis Whitley, 39, San Diego Chargers.. Greg Page, 50, boxer...Justin Levens, 28, boxer...Norman Hand, 37, New York Giants... Bennet returns, changed into a suit, then-- INT./EXT. BENNET’S CAR/CENTRAL VALLEY, CA - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Mercedes cutting fast through the oceans of crops. Factories, ranches. Schools. A high school. Now - suddenl slowing-- Pulling alongside a junior varsity football practice. The kids - mostly Mexican - strapping on helmets. That nutcra drill. As other kids are winding down. Tossing the ball. Tossing water bottles. The adolescent knucklehead hazing of rangy leggy puppies. The game as rite of passage. And we REVERSE ON BENNET. He forgets himself. It’s a litt funny. Kids. Then-- Two players line up 15 yards apart, turn to face each oth like bulls. And run. Bennet takes a step toward them as t kids hurtle forward erasing the space between them. Faste INTERCUTTING Bennet and the blur. 5-yards and closing. 2- yards. And now-- FREEZE. A single frame before helmets collide ina devastating crow-to-crown blow. HOLD there, and over that © 2015 CTMG. All Rights Reserved.  CHERRY PAGES 1.21.15 127.

dialogues.speaker: CRAWL
dialogues.text: * Bennet Omalu turned down the Washington job offer. He remains in Lodi, California, with Prema and his two child * Shortly after Hall of Fame linebacker, Junior Seau, sho himself in the heart, more than 4,500 retired NFL players sued the NFL for concealing the dangers of concussions. * The NFL proposed a settlement in which former NFL Commissioner Paul Tagliabue and Dr. Elliot Pellman would never be questioned under oath, and the League would neve have to disclose what it knew about concussion-related br problems, or when it knew it. * Last September, actuaries hired by the NFL concluded th 33% of all retired professional football players will suf “serious cognitive impairment”, including CTE, in their lifetime. * All Federal charges against Dr. Cyril Wecht were eventu dropped.
